PETITION.TITLE: Local Road Funding
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
Australians living in rural and non-urban areas rely to a great degree on the local road network for all facets of their lives.
Funding for roads is an essential part of the Commonwealth's responsibilities for the maintenance of the transport infrastructure.
Road funding under the Hawke Government has decreased significantly in real terms and local government is particularly disadvantaged by this decline.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to: Immediately address the serious problem of a rapidly deteriorating road network which is confronting local government by allocating more resources to local road funding.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray

PETITION.TITLE: Animal Patents
PETITION.PARA: To the President and members of the Australian Senate. The undersigned citizens of Australia, and custodians of the Earth, oppose the patenting of animals, and the processes for altering them. Animal patents would *reduce biodiversity, `compromise animal welfare, *concentrate ownership of breeding stock, and *allow companies to appropriate the fruit of centuries of selective breeding. We note with concern that many applications for animal patents have been lodged with the Australian Patents Office and without your intervention they may soon be approved.
Please take all possible steps immediately to ensure that:
1. The Patents Office rejects all existing applications for animal patents and declines to accept any more:
2. The Senate amends the Patents Bill 1989 to prohibit the patenting of animals.
We pray that all members of the Australian Senate will act on this petition.

PETITION.TITLE: States Grants Schools Assistance Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament the petition of the undersigned shows:

That the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Act, 1988 includes legislation, Part III-Changes to Non-Government Schools and New Non-Government Schools, designed to inhibit the establishment, growth and development of these schools in Australia by the imposition of restrictive provisions in the areas of funding, enrolments and approval criteria.

Your petitioners pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should: reconsider the applications and implications of this legislation in the light of justice, equity and freedom of choice for parents and have the unfair sections (Section 8 (2), 8 (15) and (11), repealed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not delay the Committee long. SPEECH.PARA: There are two things that arise. First, let me make it quite clear that at no stage, either in the speech I made last night or in the course of the hearings of the Estimates Committee, did I seek to imply that Mr Max Bourke, who is a public servant and who is the General Manager of the Australia Council, bore any personal or direct responsibility for the activities of the Australia Council.

What I was concerned about was not that he had been involved but two other things: first, the fact that, as a statutory authority, its expenditure of money in the production of the press release which was at issue was money out of the public purse and that the printing and distribution of that, to the extent that there was any cost involved, was a cost out of the public purse, out of public revenues, and was therefore in fact an expenditure of taxpayers' money on what was a partisan political exercise; and, secondly, that the Council purports to speak, as it were, as an authority, in exactly the same way that Qantas Airways Ltd, Australian Airlines, Overseas Telecommunications Commission Australia, Aussat Pty Ltd or any similar organisation might if it believed that one set of policies, either Government policies or Opposition policies, were contrary to what it perceived as its corporate interest.

I put this parallel to the Minister. The Government was fairly vigorous about the comments made by the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC) in terms of the debate about the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC). It said, `Look, the Government has a policy to abolish this organisation and to replace it with the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission, and it is not proper'-and we accepted that it was not proper-`for the ADC as such to become involved in that debate'. The Government has the right to determine what the structures, particularly advisory structures which report to it, should be and, if there is dispute about that, then the dispute should properly take place in the Parliament and in the public domain between the political parties.
It was on that basis, I think, that the Estimates Committee C came to the conclusion to which it did. I repeat that conclusion:
The Committee is of the view that statements of party political opinion should not be canvassed in news releases of government agencies.

I think that is the essential point of the Committee's recommendation. It is one which, I believe, organisations-whether they happen to be the Australia Council or any other statutory or advisory authority, no matter how they are composed-because of their very nature and relationship with government, should have drawn to their attention and should seek to abide by.
I conclude by asking the Minister whether he is now in a position to provide information about costs and distribution which I was assured last night would be made available.

—If that is the case, as far as I am concerned, the other documents can be put before the Estimates Committee and be public documents.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Guided by what my colleague Senator Crichton-Browne has said, and speaking on behalf of the Opposition members of Estimates Committee C, I would not press for any of that material to be made available to Estimates Committee C on the basis that the drugs in sport inquiry is in a position to accept that material on an in camera basis, or whatever basis the drugs in sport inquiry committee wishes to accept it. We will proceed on the basis that the other correspondence dealing with the substitution problem is being released to Estimates Committee C in the normal way in which documentation is released to Estimates Committee C.

SPEECH.PARA: To that extent, the Commission has discharged the obligation which it undertook to make that material available to Estimates Committee C. We would avoid any discussion of the particularities of case which Senator Crichton-Browne has identified and leave that entirely to the drugs in sport inquiry to pursue, within whatever remit it might be operating on. We should just get on with dealing with any substitution matters which Senator Crichton-Browne was discussing previously.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Events have unfolded in the way they have because we were trying to get the material as quickly as possible. There had been two requests and the head of the Minister's Department was helpful in providing it. We have got all the correspondence now, and only half was requested by the Estimates Committee. The correspondence I was referring to is between the Minister and Mr Harris. The Minister's letter states:

SPEECH.PARA: I acknowledge that funding limitations have, in the past, restricted the Commission in its capacity to operate a fully effective drug testing program. However, the additional funding appropriated to the ASC in this year's budget for the establishment or an independent Australian Sports Drug Agency (ASDA) should enable those deficiencies to be overcome.

The physical relocation of the drug testing agency, separating it from the Commission, was a desirable and timely move. I was also pleased to hear that the ASC has established a committee to oversee the work of the ASDA. I would appreciate it if its reports to that committee were automatically copied to me.

Several issues remain to be resolved with respect to the powers and conduct of the ASDA in the longer term. The co-operation of the States and Territories is being sought on the implementation of a truly national program and the matter has been listed on the agenda for the next meeting of the Sport and Recreation Minister's Council.

My Department is currently liaising with the Attorney General's Department regarding constitutional matters, criminality and privacy concerns. The issues are complex, and while they cannot be resolved quickly, I am hopeful that the appropriate legislative backing will be in place early next year. I have asked that officers of the ASDA be kept informed of developments.

The community has an expectation that strong action will be taken to eradicate drugs in sport in this country. It is of the utmost importance that the integrity and efficiency of the new drug testing agency be beyond question.

The interim report of the Senate Committee has made a number of allegations concerning drug use by Australian Institute of Sport athletes and the involvement of staff. The Inquiry has elicited sufficient scientific and anecdotal evidence to arouse suspicion. Unless there is a thorough investigation of those cases where serious doubts have been raised both the Institute and the individuals will remain suspect.

Your report of the interviews conducted by yourself and the Deputy Chairman does not make clear that a thorough investigation of the allegations elicited during the Inquiry has been carried out. I believe it is necessary for the Institute to clear its reputation and the reputation of its employees. Accordingly, I ask that the Commission review its position with the object of thoroughly investigating the allegations that have been made.

Ultimately, I will be called upon to respond to the final report when it is tabled in Parliament. Because of the intense publicity and community interest in the findings of the Black Committee, its conclusions and recommendations will be closely scrutinised. I may well be called upon to defend the actions of the Committee in response to the interim report and would appreciate your assistance in ensuring that I am able to do so convincingly.

I think that is an eminently reasonable letter. Before I turn to the response of Mr Harris I will ask one or two questions peripheral to my immediate concern but certainly not peripheral to the whole matter. Could the Minister tell me what is the status of the legislation which is to be prepared and put in place for the purpose of ensuring the integrity of the ASDA, and when we can expect that to be introduced into the Parliament?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, as you will appreciate, it is pretty difficult to get priority for legislation and get it listed. I am a member of the Government's parliamentary business committee but I cannot recall what status we have given Bills for the next session. In answer to Senator Crichton-Browne I can say that it was my intention when I was Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories that this Bill would be dealt with this year.

SPEECH.PARA: Once the election was announced and I realised there would be a very short parliamentary session in the autumn I did not think it would get through in the autumn session, but I was always confident it would go through in the Budget session of the Parliament. I intend to do my utmost on the parliamentary business committee to give the Bill the highest priority. I am fairly confident that I will get that, and that it will definitely be dealt with in the Budget session.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister made the point:

SPEECH.PARA: The community has an expectation that strong action will be taken to eradicate drugs in sport in this country. It is of the utmost importance that the integrity and efficiency of the new drug testing agency be beyond question.

I assume that the Minister was also saying to Mr Harris that those in a position of responsibility ought to be seen by their very conduct and actions to be expressing their abhorrence at the use of performance-enhancing drugs and that they would conduct themselves in such a way as to assure the public that it was not to be tolerated.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I think that is correct. I think that was what I was saying to Mr Harris. I made that point to him, to many of the people who have been prominent in Australian sport over the last few years and to the Australian Sports Commission. Indeed, the Institute has made numerous statements to that effect.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —During the Estimates Committee hearings the Minister will recall that I raised the matter of a social and community research report which was commissioned by the Australian Institute of Sport (AIS). I came by that document after about 29 phone calls to the Institute. I just put on the record that almost nobody had heard of it, notwithstanding that it cost $8,500. I will not press the words, but I asked Mr Crosswhite why the report had been commissioned. In due course, the Minister might like to reflect upon his answer because, in my view, it was not truthful to the extent that was necessary. The reason the report was commissioned, according to the Department, was that it was a social and community research survey to respond to the Senate Standing Committee on the Environment, Recreation and the Arts inquiry into the use of performance-enhancing drugs in sport. That was the main reason. It went on to say that it was to respond to corporate sponsors, and develop public communication strategies for the Australian Institute of Sport.

SPEECH.PARA: Any sensible reading of that would tell one that the decision to commission that report was made because of concern amongst senior executives of the Australian Institute of Sport that they were suffering some damage as a result of public perception of their conduct, the conduct of some coaches and further, the conduct of some athletes. It would have been much more sensible if Mr Crosswhite had simply said that at the outset rather than having given me waffle about corporate sponsors and so on. The only reason why corporate sponsors may have come into it is that they might have been concerned about continuing to give funding as a result of the drugs in sport inquiry. I do not chide beyond saying that, but it makes life easier for us if we get straight answers.

The research showed a number of matters which, I think, reflect Senator Richardson's instinct for public perception. Eighty-eight per cent of those surveyed said that the AIS should publicly condemn the idea of athletes using drugs in sport-right up front. In an explanation, the researchers say that the results suggest that the AIS should take a strong and high profile position on the issue. The most significant direction for AIS action would be to publicly condemn the idea of athletes using drugs in sport. It goes on to say that the community does expect the AIS to take a strong position on the issue.

Some might say that we are outraged by the use of drugs in sport, but we are horrified. We think their application is reprehensible and we deal in a direct and particular way when the occasion calls for it. I think honourable senators will agree that the two reports that have so far been put down have been fair, objective and bipartisan. The response from the Australian Sports Commission hardly reflects what it discovered after spending $8,500 of taxpayers' money, which was required of it by the community.

I think the Minister's correspondence to the Commission highlights that very point. He makes the points that the public has strong expectations, that he will be required to defend the Commission in due course, that he will have to respond to the reports and that there is sufficient evidence of a scientific and anecdotal nature to arouse suspicion-and that was a generous way of putting it, crafting it so as to say no more. The golden thread of the correspondence is that the Commission is expected to act in a constructive and proper way when confronted with evidence in respect of the conduct of officials and athletes of the Australian Institute of Sport.
I ask the Minister whether he is satisfied with Mr Harris's response to his letter. In a rather gratuitous tone, speaking for himself and Mr Coates, Mr Harris states:
We are both at a loss to understand your statement.
He then quotes the Minister:
Your report of the interviews conducted by yourself and the Deputy Chairman does not make clear that a thorough investigation of the allegations elicited during the Inquiry has been carried out.
Can the Minister explain why he might be at a loss to understand simple language used in the correspondence?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Crichton-Browne has raised a number of issues. I would like to cover them before answering the last question. First off, I refer to his reference to Mr Crosswhite. I thought that under difficult circumstances at the Estimates Committee he performed admirably and was prepared to be honest even to the point of casting doubt upon his own judgment in terms of a promotion that he had recommended for someone at the Australian Institute of Sport. I thought he performed very well and was prepared to be very open and honest with the Committee. On that basis Mr Crosswhite has my full confidence and support.

SPEECH.PARA: On the matter of the research to which Senator Crichton-Browne has referred, 88 per cent of people said that they thought drugs in sport were a bad idea and that the Institute ought to come out publicly and condemn their use. Of course both the Institute and the Australian Sports Commission have done that many times. I do not think it is the case that it always gets front page coverage, but they have continually decried the use of drugs in sport and called for harsh penalties for those who transgress. When it came to the investigation of some allegations, my concern was that the correspondence I had received from Mr Harris was not conclusive as to whether or not a thorough investigation had occurred.

I have to say that those of us who know Ted Harris know that he responds, very often, in strong tones, and he did so again. It is a good appointment; I am not opposing it. I am making the point that Mr Harris, when he feels that someone is questioning him, very often reacts angrily. I received from Mr Harris the kind of correspondence he is accustomed to writing, so I was not greatly offended by it.

I think at the time the Department drafted me another letter to send back, which I do not think I sent. My recollection is that I spoke to Mr Harris on the telephone about this incident. I received, over the phone, his assurances that the interviews that had been conducted by himself and Mr Coates had been thorough, that they had well and truly canvassed the issues and that the conclusions they had come to were based on a proper investigation. The simple point was that I had not been satisfied, on the basis of the correspondence I had received, that the investigation had been thorough enough. That was why I wrote the letter that Senator Crichton-Browne has read out. I do not think that the response I received from Mr Harris helped me at all in coming to the conclusion that a proper investigation had been conducted, but after a telephone conversation with him, I was satisfied.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was obvious to me, in respect of Mr Crosswhite, that he was, to use the Minister's words, `under difficult circumstances'. I am not aware of what they were, but I found him, almost without exception, unable to answer the thrust and the heart of the questions that were put to him. In respect of matters germane to substance, he retreated to tell us what the Commission had decided. I do not know whether that is Mr Harris's manner and style of operation. I refer the Minister to two paragraphs of this letter:

SPEECH.PARA: Whilst it is vital that the Institute ensures that its reputation and that of its employees is beyond question, it is also necessary that Honourable Senators should understand-
I do not know whether he is talking about the Minister or me; perhaps both-

that it is un-Australian and unacceptable for unreasonable and unsubstantiated conclusions to be drawn under the cloak of ``Parliamentary privileges'' and for such conclusions to lead to the good name and reputation of athletes being impugned.

You should be aware that within the sporting community throughout Australia, there is much discomfort in respect of the manner in which Parliamentary privilege is being used to engaged in heresy hunts. I speak on behalf of all members of the Australian Sports Commission in making it plain to you and to other Honourable Senators that the Commission is determined to preserve two overriding principles.
I ask: What were the unreasonable and unsubstantiated conclusions drawn under parliamentary privilege which led to the good name and reputation of athletes being impugned?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —First, I will table the two letters that we are now talking about so that they are available to the Committee. I am getting the other correspondence that I need to put before the Committee. I will hang on to the two letters for the moment while I answer Senator Crichton-Browne's questions, but I will table them. I am asked what are the unsubstantiated conclusions drawn under the cloak of parliamentary privilege. I think it is fairly obvious: I never said there were any. It is not up to me to answer that question; it will be up to Mr Harris. I certainly would not attempt to answer it.
—Did you write back and ask him?

—I do not believe that I need to do that. It is not my responsibility. Even if I were still the Minister with responsibility for sport, it would not by my responsibility. If the Australian Sports Commission is aggrieved by the activities of the drugs in sport inquiry by the Standing Committee on the Environment, Recreation and the Arts, that is a matter for it. As Senator Crichton-Browne well knows, a lot of people in sport are aggrieved by the Committee. Whether that is right or wrong is not the point.
—That is the point.

—It is not the point, with great respect. It is certainly not the point of a Minister's responsibility, and I do not intend to take responsibility for the attitudes that Mr Harris, Mr Coates or any other member of the board of the Australian Sports Commission, or anybody in Australian sport at all, want to take in regard to the Committee's two reports. The reality is that this is still a democracy and, if people do not like what a Senate committee does, then they are going to express their dislike for it; and I do not think that any expression of their dislike for the activities of a Senate committee is necessarily the responsibility of a Minister.

SPEECH.PARA: I go back to Senator Crichton-Browne's remarks about Mr Crosswhite, which I strongly reject. I think that Mr Crosswhite went to very great lengths to answer questions at the Committee hearing. Senator Crichton-Browne asked: What difficult circumstances? There are those of us who think that on occasions Senator Crichton-Browne can be difficult and that perhaps this Estimates Committee hearing was just another one of those occasions.

TALK.START.PARA: —I certainly was not seeking to be difficult. It was the answers that made life difficult.
—I am sure Senator Crichton-Browne never seeks to be difficult, and perhaps he is not. Perhaps it is just the totally unreasonable judgment of a great majority of Australia's population that he is.
—You speak on behalf of them, do you, Senator Richardson?
—As a member of that majority--
—You got 35 per cent of the votes in Western Australia.
—I keep hearing this from Senator Crichton-Browne. The fact is that when preferences were distributed we finished way in front of the Liberal Party and did not lose a seat.
—Order! The discussion on the election is irrelevant to this debate.

—It is interesting, nonetheless. But I abide by your ruling, Mr Chairman. I am sorry to have responded to a difficult interjection from a difficult senator. Under difficult circumstances I thought that Mr Crosswhite went to great lengths to provide a lot of answers. It is clear that in a number of these instances which we are now discussing Mr Crosswhite could not possibly have been privy to what went on behind a closed door. He was not included as a member of an interviewing panel in these investigations and so could not answer some of the questions that Senator Crichton-Browne was asking, and it is unfair for Senator Crichton-Browne in the Committee of the Whole to cast aspersions on him for that inability.
—No, I was not. I will clarify that.
—It certainly sounded like that to me, and I have full confidence in the gentleman concerned. I thought at the Estimates Committee he performed admirably.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me make it clear, first of all, that I was less than satisfied with the answer Mr Crosswhite gave. I will read it out, if it needs to be read out, to convince Senator Richardson about that. In my view, one of the problems at the Australian Institute of Sport (AIS) is that the Acting Executive Director is kept in the dark and behind closed doors on almost every subject of substance, if I am any judge. Let me embellish on what the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson) is implying. Mr Harris is very autocratic and domineering, and is determined to get his way-I will say it and the Minister will not-in spite of the facts. As long as that happens, Mr Crosswhite is going to find life pretty difficult when it comes to the Estimates Committee. If life goes on the way it is at the Institute and if by then somebody has been found to work with him, at the next Estimates Committee his life is not going to be much better.

SPEECH.PARA: I have got grave reservations about the appointment of the head of the AIS as regards how that was done-and I will come to that later in the Estimates. I have got grave reservations about the objective and impartial examination of the interim report that Mr Harris has undertaken. Frankly, I want to say as a caring Australian that, if that Commission does not get its act together, it is going to cause the Government the same sorts of problems that the Aboriginal Development Commission caused the Government. Is the Minister now satisfied with the Commission's response to the interim report of the Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts?

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the Minister answers that I think a brief answer will be in order but that particular matter is not before the Committee at the moment. We are considering the correspondence on substitution of an athlete's urine sample used in a drug test. In so far as the report is relevant to that the Minister would be in order to answer but a general answer to the whole report would not be in order at this time.
—The urine substitution is part of the report.
—I am trying to make it clear that only that part is relevant for answer by the Minister.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am now satisfied with the Commission's response in so far as I believe it has fully investigated the allegations of a serious nature that came within its ambit in the Committee's first report. I reject Senator Crichton-Browne's description of Mr Harris as either autocratic or domineering. The difficulties in finding suitable senior officers at the Institute and the Commission have absolutely nothing to do with Senator Crichton-Browne's allegation of finding somebody who will work with him. That is nonsense. They have everything to do with the very poor salary package we have been offering when the reality is that top sports administrators around the country are getting double what we are offering. We are finding it very difficult to attract people of real quality on the money and packages available. Mr Harris has been doing his very best to try to get that package upped considerably so that we may be in a position to get the right kind of people. The hunt goes on.

SPEECH.PARA: In terms of the Commission's response to allegations made about sports and individuals who are the recipients of the Australian Sports Commission funding-and that is the extent of its obligation-then I am satisfied with its response.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister to what I assume is a summation by the Commission of the Jane Flemming matter. In response to criticisms Jane Flemming acknowledges that she should not have participated in the urine substitution. Maurice Plant was the team manager. She had known and respected him. He had helped her in her sport. She was 21 years old, it was her first major trip overseas and her first major team.

SPEECH.PARA: Before I go any further I ask whether the Minister is satisfied that for an athlete to be 21 years old and on her first trip is some sort of mitigating circumstance for participating in the urine substitution racket?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not regard this incident, serious though it undoubtedly was, as part of a racket. That is lifting it to a plane which, on any reading of the circumstances at the time, it could possibly never reach.
—I am talking about that one circumstance.

—I know exactly what Senator Crichton-Browne is talking about. Suggesting it is a urine substitution racket is just nonsense. I reject that totally. If one takes into account all of the circumstances, not to mention the fact that the matter is four years old, one wonders what more the Australian Sports Commission can do. It has admonished the athlete concerned. I am not certain that for a four year old incident there was much more it can reasonably be expected to do.

SPEECH.PARA: The athlete concerned has paid a very high price indeed to her reputation. Anyone who has looked at a television, turned on a radio or read a newspaper today knows all about it. For an incident which I am certain she did not regard at the time as being of serious moment she has paid a very high price indeed. That is one athlete who will never transgress, I can assure honourable senators of that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps the Minister is not aware of it-if he is not I will enlighten him, as he is the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mrs Kelly) in this place-but urine substitution is a well known racket and a notorious form of cheating which is specifically outlawed by the International Olympic Commission.

SPEECH.PARA: In respect of Miss Flemming's present circumstances, as I said yesterday when I was speaking to the tabling of the report, I find it painfully regrettable that it is still on the agenda. I do not make judgments about what she did; that is not my task. I have no doubt that she has considerable remorse. Under the circumstances, that can be understood. My view is that if the Commission had acted in a proper, responsible and sensitive way at the time I would not be standing here now asking the Minister questions and he would not be standing there answering them.

But to the extent that the Commission has compromised everybody, it leaves me no choice. The Commission said, by way of explanation for its judgment of the penalty and in explaining its inquiry, that Miss Flemming volunteered to appear before the Committee. The response of Mr Harris to our recommendations and finding was:

She provided evidence in camera, but it was published. She considers that the Committee's attitude was to treat her as guilty until proved innocent, rather than the reverse. She has been greatly disturbed by her appearance before the Committee.

Miss Flemming wrote to the Standing Committee on the Environment, Recreation and the Arts and volunteered to appear before it. In fact, so enthusiastic was the Commission that Mr Bowman rang on her behalf. I will not use the language he used about other athletes when he encouraged us to hear her evidence, because I think that is inappropriate. But she was coming over not to confess to urine substitution; she was coming over to pay out on previous witnesses who had made allegations in respect of drug taking at the Institute. That is why she was coming. In fact, her written submission was in essence:
I am writing to request a chance to voice my opinion as an Olympic Games, Commonwealth Games and Australian Institute of Sport athlete regarding the inquiry into drugs in sport.

She said that she was surprised to hear that it had been suggested that as many as 25 to 30 per cent of Australian Institute of Sport (AIS) athletes had used banned drugs. She said she knew nothing about it herself. She referred to the fact that she was looking forward to hearing from us and would be most willing to answer questions.
When Miss Flemming came before us, in essence to give evidence on behalf of the Australian Institute of Sport, she said in the opening comments:
I am basically here to support the Institute of Sport on some of the allegations that have been made against it. I have been at the Institute for four years'.

That was her reason for being before us. She did not seek to present her evidence in camera. She did not volunteer the information that she had been involved in urine substitution. In fact, she was asked by the Chairman whether she knew anything about urine substitution. He said:
Do you have any knowledge of either that practice or of the provision of clean urine samples by athletes for others?
Miss Flemming answered:

I have heard of that sort of thing going on and I have also heard of people who have been tested and had positive results, not in Australia, but internationally. That has not become public knowledge and therefore they have never got the sort of ban placed on them.
The Chairman, after a number of questions, said:
Have you ever been asked to provide a clean urine sample for anybody?
That was the first Miss Flemming knew of the material we had before us. She then said:
I would like to talk about that evidence in camera.

Now, the inquiry did not learn from Miss Flemming, as a result of her evidence, either public or in camera, that she had been involved in urine substitution. That information was made known to the Committee by a number of sources, all of whom had been told by Miss Flemming in the belief by her that she was speaking to them in confidence. She then sought to have her evidence in camera for a number of reasons, not the least being, to use her expression, that it would damage her with her sponsors.

Honourable senators know the rules as well as I do: one takes evidence in camera and then makes a judgment about it afterwards. Miss Flemming did not come before the Committee with the attitude of mea culpa, mea culpa, mea maxima culpa. She came to pay out on some other athletes and learned as a result of other evidence what we were aware of. So, to reflect upon the findings of Mr Harris, she volunteered to appear before the Committee. That is true. She provided evidence in camera but it was published. We now know about the circumstances of that. Mr Harris said:
She considers that the Committee's attitude was to treat her as guilty until proved innocent rather than the reverse.

I find that a remarkable statement by Mr Harris. We had already received evidence; we asked her the question, and then she said yes. I am not aware that under any circumstance Miss Flemming has denied it-and it is to her credit-although Mr Rice is now challenging that, as honourable senators know, and that was the matter raised at the Estimates Committee hearing. Up until that point it had never been suggested, to my knowledge, that there was any doubt about Miss Flemming's guilt. But it is used presumably as the basis of the determination by Mr Harris.

On the basis of that, I ask Senator Richardson whether he would not be vaguely concerned about the grounds that Mr Harris used to impose the penalty he did on Miss Flemming, which was to write and say that she had done something wrong.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have now a copy of all the correspondence with which we have been dealing, and I make that available to the Committee so that everyone will know where we are up to. The actual response to Jane Flemming by the Australian Sports Commission (ASC) was conveyed on 12 October 1989 in a letter to Miss Flemming by Mr Harris. I will just read a bit of that letter, a copy of which Senator Crichton-Browne has, because it sets out what the Commission's response to this was. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: You will recall that the Deputy Chairman, Mr John Coates, and I met with you on 5 July to discuss this matter and that at that time we admonished you for your role in the incident. While we acknowledged the circumstances surrounding your participation, we made it clear that the Commission will not take the incident lightly or condone your role.

The Commission of the Australian Sports Commission met on 13 July and considered the Senate Committee's Interim Report and a report arising from our meeting on 5 July. I now write to inform you that the Commission confirms Mr Coates and my disapproval of your participation in the urine substitution incident and views the matter with concern. Had it not been that you were young at the time, on your first major trip as a member of the Australian Commonwealth Games Team and following the instructions of your Assistant Manager, we would have terminated your scholarship. If there is ever any repetition or other breach of our doping policy you can expect instant dismissal.
You and all other athletes must understand that since the Belfast incident the AIS/ASC doping policy now-
not an unimportant word in this context-
clearly states that any activity to subvert a drug testing process constitutes a breach of the policy and is punishable by dismissal and a life ban from competition.

That is a pretty heavy letter to be writing to an athlete; it is not one that the Commission, via Mr Harris, would ever undertake to do lightly. I think it, very correctly, underlines their concern about the incident.

But I think it is also making the point that we have seen in the four intervening years since 1986 a marked change in community attitudes to the use of drugs in sport. Recognising that community change, the ASC and the Australian Institute of Sport have very much tightened their own policies and penalties in relation to drug testing in sport.

So the case, as I view it, is that Mr Harris and Mr Coates investigated the incident and reported to the Commission. Miss Flemming was informed of just how much concern the Commission had and was told that any breach would result in a life ban and dismissal from the Institute. That is about as far as the Commission could take this matter in the circumstances that prevailed at the time. So I am satisfied with the Commission's response; it is quite clear that Senator Crichton-Browne is not. There is a difference of opinion between the honourable senator and the Commission as to the way in which the Flemming incident should have been handled.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Committee.
—All right, between the Commission and the Committee. I do not intend today to respond, on behalf of the Government, to the Committee's report. It was presented yesterday and I would imagine--
—I am talking about the interim report.
—I know what the honourable senator is talking about.
—You are disguising it.

—No, I am not disguising it. Senator Crichton-Browne cannot disguise the fact that during the last hour he has raised a number of things that came up in the report that was presented yesterday. As far as I am concerned, we have to try, as a government, to deal with the reports of the Committee. We have to try to come up with a proper, lengthy and considered response to lengthy reports which are raising matters of very great community concern. I will not be in a position today to respond to a whole series of incidents and issues that have been covered in those reports. I do not regard that as either proper or my responsibility. Rather, that is up to the Government to do over time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —If I am so discursive and inarticulate that the Minister cannot understand me, I apologise. I make it clear that I have not once referred to the report presented yesterday. Every single thing to which I have referred has related exclusively to the interim report. My comments in respect of Mr Harris, his explanation and his excuse, are in response to the interim report.
—It is very hard to exclude Jane Flemming from yesterday's report, isn't it?

—Jane Flemming was referred to in detail on pages and pages of the first report, regrettably. The report yesterday said that we were dissatisfied with the Commission's response to the interim report. There is, essentially, nothing new in that report except that Mr Rice now alleges that Jane Flemming lied under oath to the Committee. I am just not in a position to make a judgment about that and I do not propose to. But everything else flows directly from the interim report.

SPEECH.PARA: I would not expect the Minister to be able to respond in general terms to the report presented yesterday. I am referring to the Commission's response to the interim report. Before we disagree about the penalty, let us see whether we can agree that the foundation upon which that penalty was built has substance and merit and has the Minister's support.

Those grounds are, at the risk of repeating myself, that she volunteered to appear before the Committee-which she did-but she volunteered because she was coming across, as she said herself in both her written and oral evidence, to defend the AIS and Peter Bowman had rung us to make sure that she got a guernsey.

Ms Flemming did not provide her evidence in camera. She asked for it to be taken in camera when she learnt not that her evidence was damaging, but that questions in respect of a matter which she did not know was within our knowledge were to be raised. Part of the foundation of her response was that she considered the Committee's attitude was to treat her as guilty until proved innocent, rather than the reverse. The Committee did not treat her as either innocent or guilty. We simply said, `Have you been involved in urine substitution?' When the extent of our knowledge of that matter finally dawned upon her, she confessed. When she was asked in a general sense on the public record whether she had any knowledge of either that practice-that is, that revolting practice of injecting urine into somebody else's bladder-or of the provision of clean urine samples by athletes for others, which is what she did, she said that she had heard of that sort of thing going on, but had also heard of people who had been tested and had a positive result, not in Australia but internationally. She said that had not become public knowledge and therefore they never got any sort of ban placed on them. Presumably she was suggesting that if they had been caught, they should have had a ban placed on them.

That was Jane Flemming's response to a general question. The most generous interpretation I can put on it is that because the particular question in respect of herself was not asked, she did not respond. But a truthful answer to that question would have been, `Senator Black and Mr Chairman, I have heard of it, and in fact I have participated in it. I can give you first hand evidence of how it works.' But she did not. It was only when she was asked later on-and this is about 10 or 15 questions later on-`Have you ever been asked to provide a clean urine sample for anybody?', suddenly her response was, `I would like to talk about that evidence in camera'. On she went.

So I ask the Minister how he can give some support to the Commission who, as an explanation for the penalty, said that she volunteered to appear before the Committee, she provided evidence in camera-but it was published-she considers that the Committee's attitude was to treat her as guilty until proved innocent rather than the reverse, and that she has been greatly disturbed by her appearance before the Committee?

I do not wish to read it out, but I will read it out if the Committee wants me to. What disturbed her was, as she said, that it might damage her reputation and cause her difficulties with her sponsors. That is what distressed her, not the objectionable questioning by Senator Crichton-Browne in his inimitable fashion. Yet they are the reasons given by Mr Harris for writing a letter to Jane Flemming telling her that she had done wrong. We all know what the International Olympic Committee says about that sort of thing. The IOC list of doping classes and methods states that the IOC Medical Commission bans the use of substances and methods which alter the integrity and validity of urine samples used in doping controls. Examples of banned methods include urine substitution. That is the IOC's view. Are the premises upon which is based the determination of the Commission to respond in the way it has reasonable and accurate?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I first point out that, if people interested in the report produced yesterday were to turn to pages 22, 23, 24, 25, 26, 27 or indeed 28, they might get a rough idea that the Flemming incident was covered in the report tabled yesterday along with every single matter that Senator Crichton-Browne has covered today, so he should not raise furphies and say that it is referred to only in the first report, and that he is not referring to anything in the report tabled yesterday. I am afraid that no-one in Australia will pick the distinction and, having flicked through those pages, neither do I. I do not withdraw those remarks. What I said was a fact-an absolutely undeniable fact, even for Senator Crichton-Browne at his most difficult.

SPEECH.PARA: I will get back to the Flemming incident and the way in which the Australian Sports Commission handled it. In November 1987, the Commission and the Australian Institute of Sport introduced a policy which would result in a life ban for transgression against that policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Institute did.

—And the Australian Sports Commission; they both did-in November 1987. We are dealing with an incident that took place in 1986. It is certainly true that since 1986 the International Olympic Committee, individual sports like athletics, the Sports Commission and the Institute of Sport have all tightened up. They have introduced very strict policies on drugs in sport, and rightly so. Those policies did not exist in 1986. I am absolutely certain that, if evidence was now produced of an incident like this, the offender would be out for life. There is no question about that. But it did not happen now; it happened a long time ago.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government, in responding to the report that was brought down yesterday-I repeat, yesterday-will have to respond to the matters now raised by Senator Crichton-Browne, and no doubt it will. But the Government will not be giving any more responses to those incidents than what I have given today, and I do not intend to keep responding. I have made my position clear. Obviously, I await consideration of the report tabled yesterday, which covers these incidents and to which the Government must respond. I will await Mrs Kelly's response when she puts it to the Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister to pages 353 through to 365 of the interim report.
—And 22 to 28 of this one.

—If the Minister wants to discuss this one, that is his business; I am discussing the interim report, pages 353 to 365. The matters touching upon the circumstances surrounding the substitution of urine by Jane Flemming are contained in the interim report-nowhere else. The new report, the report of yesterday, which we ought not to be discussing, simply retraces the recommendations of the Committee in expressing its disapproval of the Commission's response.

SPEECH.PARA: I bring Senator Richardson back to the Commission's explanation for drawing the conclusion and the recommendation-which I have not yet read out, but I will if the Minister wants-in respect of Miss Flemming. I am sure the Minister must understand what I have said four times already-that she volunteered to appear before the Committee; she provided evidence in camera but it was published; she considered the Committee's attitude was to treat her as guilty until proven innocent, rather than the reverse and she has been greatly disturbed by her appearance before the Committee. I ask Senator Richardson whether those are good grounds for arriving at any conclusion.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have gone through the response of the Commission several times. As far as I am concerned any further comment on this from the Government will await our consideration of the report.

—The document to which I refer is a report prepared by the Australian Sports Commission as a response to the interim report. The particular interview with Miss Jane Flemming to which I refer took place on 5 July 1989, following the presentation in this chamber of the interim report. Let us not talk about the second report and findings, conclusions and responses from that; we are talking about the interim report. The response of the Commission in respect to Miss Flemming is as read out by me in paragraph (b). I am asking, in response to the findings of the interim report, whether the Minister is satisfied that the grounds presented to him by the Commission in response to his request are reasons for imposing a penalty of any nature.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am satisfied with the extent of the investigation carried out by the Australian Sports Commission. As the Minister responsible at the time, it was my duty to find out how far the Commission had gone in investigating the allegations about drugs in sport and their use by Commission and Institute of Sport athletes. As a result of the inquiries I made I was and am satisfied at the extent of the investigations. In respect of the actions that have been taken since, I have already said that I regard the letter sent to Jane Flemming and its contents as sufficient punishment. I do not really believe that the Commission could or should take it further than it has.

SPEECH.PARA: On the more general question, I am not aware of the Government as yet tabling a response to the interim report-the interim report was also a lengthy one-and the Government will be responding to the interim report and to this one, one would imagine, in one go, not in two. Today I do not wish to pre-empt the Government's response to those reports. That is a matter to be more properly dealt with by Mrs Kelly making a submission to Government. I am absolutely certain that Jane Flemming has paid a sufficient penalty for whatever transgressions she may have committed in the past. I do not believe that the continued canvassing of this issue is in the interests of Australian sport. Accordingly, I do not propose to canvass it any further.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister's correspondence to Mr Harris, which I read out and which was tabled earlier, was dated 24 November 1989; it was directly as a result of what I am reading out now. The Minister wrote back to Mr Harris. Blind Freddy can see from the Minister's correspondence that he was not satisfied with the findings or the level of investigation.

SPEECH.PARA: I ask Senator Richardson a simple question: Given his knowledge and that of his advisers, does he believe the explanation given by the Commission in making these recommendations-that Miss Flemming volunteered to appear before the Committee, which is totally and absolutely misleading; that she provided evidence in camera, which again is totally and absolutely misleading because it was not her evidence but the evidence of others that led us to understand the truth of the matter, and that she considered the Committee's attitude was to treat her as guilty until proven innocent rather than the reverse-was reasonable? Are those reasonable grounds for drawing any conclusions and recommendations, whatever the findings or penalty might be? Are they reasonable grounds upon which to write a report and send it to the Minister to tell him why Miss Flemming got the penalty that she did?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Crichton-Browne should not read too much into all this. The Commission investigated this incident. There is no question that in that investigation it found Jane Flemming guilty of participating in a urine substitution incident, as it called it. The Commission saw fit to comment on her appearance before the drugs in sport committee. I do not agree with all the views expressed collectively, or individually, by members of the Commission on the proceedings that took place before the drugs in sport committee: I do not believe that I need to.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that the commissioners, and the Commission itself, are entitled to a view about the way the Committee conducted itself. I believe that all Australians are entitled to a view about the way the Committee conducted its proceedings; but I do not have to share it. I will not take part in an exercise where I tell the Commission, individual commissioners or athletes that they are not allowed to think ill of a Senate committee-of course they are.

We have not got to the stage yet where people are going to be arrested for saying that they did not like the way a Senate committee proceeded. It is pretty obvious that Jane Flemming was not all that keen on the Senate committee. She expressed that view to the Commission. I have already made it clear that individual commissioners and the Commission have received criticism of the way the Committee conducted itself-as have administrators in quite a number of sports that were touched upon by the Committee's deliberations.

The reality is that the Commission accepted that Jane Flemming did the wrong thing. It wrote to her and said that it now had a policy for bringing about a life ban for people who did such a thing and that if she did it again she would be out for life. One wonders what more the Commission can do about a four-year-old incident. That is what the drugs in sport inquiry ought to be looking at and that is what the Committee of the Whole ought to look at. I have said that I am satisfied with this result, and I am.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —For reasons which are fundamentally obvious to me, Senator Richardson is labouring the penalty. I will continue to labour the grounds for which the penalty was imposed. I understand that Senator Richardson does not have to agree with the Commission, the Commission does not have to agree with the Committee, the Committee does not have to agree with the Commission and the Committee does not have to agree with the Minister, but that is all a bit irrelevant.

SPEECH.PARA: I ask Senator Richardson, as the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories in this place, and as the Minister responsible for that portfolio at the time, whether he is satisfied that the excuse given-or the explanation, if I want to be generous-by the Commission for imposing the penalty, whatever it was, was that Jane Flemming volunteered to appear before the Committee and provided evidence in camera but it was published, that she considered the Committee's attitude was to treat her as guilty until proven innocent rather than the reverse, and that she has been greatly disturbed by her appearance before the Committee. The simple question I ask the Minister is whether, in his mind, those are fair and reasonable grounds for drawing any conclusion as to guilt, innocence or penalty?

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I think I have answered this question a number of times and, apparently, I am unable to answer it to Senator Crichton-Browne's satisfaction. That is a great shock to me. He says what is obvious to him, and then refers to blind Freddy, although I will not attempt to raise the spectre of the visually impaired. All I can say is that the reason for the penalty is not a statement that Jane Flemming appeared voluntarily before the Committee-which she did-or anything else. The reason for the penalty is that the Commission found that Jane Flemming had participated in a urine substitution incident, found that this occurred prior to its adoption of a doping policy in November 1987, and informed her that now that that policy was alive and well, she would not be in so far as sport is concerned, if she transgressed again. It will not matter how many times I am asked the question, that will be my response.

—That is a response to a different question and the Minister knows it. I can understand him hanging in there with that response. I wonder whether he might focus on the question before he prepares the answer. I ask: is the Minister himself satisfied that any of the explanations given are a foundation for drawing any conclusions? Is it relevant whether she appeared before the Committee voluntarily? Does the Minister accept what she has told the Committee, and that is that she came along to defend the Commission and bag other athletes? Does the Minister accept that she did not ask for her evidence to be taken in camera until such time as it began to reflect adversely on her? Does the Minister accept that she was never treated by anybody as guilty, contrary to natural justice? Does the Minister accept that Jane Flemming being disturbed by the Committee in some way is a suitable response to the penalty? The Minister knows what I am saying. I do not want to have to ask each of these questions individually.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The actual words appear under the heading `Response to criticisms', not under the heading `The reasons why we made the penalty were these'. That fact seems to have been left out of all the questions Senator Crichton-Browne has been asking. The reason why I am hanging in there, as Senator Crichton-Browne put it, is that, as a response to criticisms, I believe that the Commission is entitled to make the response. That does not mean I agree with it.

SPEECH.PARA: Do I think that a committee chaired by Senator Black, with Senator Crichton-Browne as the Deputy Chairman, would treat people as guilty until proven innocent? The answer to that is no. I do not accept that the Committee would have behaved in that fashion-not for a second. Do I accept that Jane Flemming was greatly disturbed by her appearance before the Committee? Too right I do.

Do I accept that she volunteered to appear before the Committee? Yes, I do. She certainly did volunteer to appear before the Committee, so I do not think that Senator Crichton-Browne can suggest that she did not. Do I accept that she provided evidence in camera, but it was published? Well, that is probably going a bit far, so I am not certain I want to accept that sentence either. But I do not have to accept any of these sentences. My acceptance or rejection of any one of them does not mean a thing. These are there as responses to criticisms. They are not there as justifications for penalties.

If Senator Crichton-Browne wants to talk about justifications for penalties and about the attitude the Commission took to the Jane Flemming incident, he should refer to the letter of 12 October. I read most of that letter into the transcript. It makes it very clear that the Commission took a very strong exception to what Jane Flemming did and wrote to her in very strong terms indeed. The Commission does not write many letters to people saying, `You have got to understand that since the Belfast incident the doping policy now clearly states that any activity to subvert a drug testing process constitutes a breach of the policy and is punishable by dismissal and a life ban.' Such letters are not written every day. That is a very serious letter. It is obviously a matter of grave concern to the Commission. It is not a question of going through the responses to criticisms saying, `Do I accept this and do I accept that?'. I do not accept that the drugs in sport committee behaved improperly; obviously I do not accept that. But there are people in the community who believe it. I do not intend to act as a thought policeman who goes around saying to people. `You are not allowed to think ill of the Committee'. I cannot and will not do that.

TALK.START.PARA: —I don't want you to.

—Senator Crichton-Browne certainly is trying to get me to head in that direction today. I will not be in it. As far as I am concerned, responses to criticisms do not amount to justification of the penalty. That is the distinction Senator Crichton-Browne is not making in his mind and is not making in this debate, but it is a distinction that must, nevertheless, be made. I have made it and I am sticking to it.

—Not unlike any other politician who has been in this place for very long, I do not much care what any athlete or administrator thinks of members of the Committee individually or collectively. One does one's job and one does it in the best way possible. If people do not like it or do not agree, that is too bad. I do not much care whether the Committee gets criticised or not, and I do not know why Senator Richardson makes that point because I had not made it and I had not sought to elicit from him his support for the Committee.
—You asked a question on the attitude about guilty and innocent. You asked the question. Of course you are concerned.
—Which question is the Minister referring to?

—Mr Chairman, I am sorry to have done that by way of interjection. I got carried away. I should have responded through you. Senator Crichton-Browne directly asked me whether I accepted that the Committee's attitude was to treat her as guilty until proven innocent rather than the reverse. He actually asked me the question. One can only assume--
—I asked about the ground.
—Frankly, I do not think anyone listening to this debate would accept that that is why Senator Crichton-Browne asked it. No-one would.

—I did not ask Senator Richardson a number of questions because I am delicate, fragile and sensitive to criticisms by the Commission or anybody else. I asked him those questions individually because collectively he seems to be unable or unprepared to answer them. Under `responses to criticisms', which is another way of saying `our explanation for the penalties'--
—It is not.

—What is the point in writing to Senator Richardson? They have written to him outlining the outcome of the inquiry and the recommendations. They might as well have put down the colour of the clothes she was wearing on the day. It is about as relevant as the rest of his interpretation of it. I asked him those questions to seek to lead him to answer the question as to whether or not, on that basis, it is proper and appropriate for the recommendations flowing immediately underneath to be as they are. The reason I asked him whether or not Jane Flemming considered the Committee's attitude was to treat her as guilty until proved innocent was simply to ask him whether or not that is a ground for the recommendations that flow. Why bother to put it in? Who cares what she thinks? Who cares whether she thinks she was treated badly or not? I do not care. Why would the Minister put that in a report of the Commission's findings and its conclusions?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has to be understood that I received correspondence from the Australian Sports Commission about the actions it had taken. I wrote back because, on the face of it, the letter did not satisfy me that a thorough investigation had taken place, and so I subsequently spoke to Mr Harris about it. The suggestion that I was satisfied with the correspondence that I had received is obviously not the case, or I would not have bothered writing the letter in the first place. But that does not change the discussion that we are having now at all. Senator Crichton-Browne is continually distorting what response to criticisms means. It does not mean justification for penalty. I cannot read that into any part of this.
—Why put it in?
—There is no question that the Sports Commission is entitled to put in a view. Senator Crichton-Browne says, `Why put it in?'. He is only concentrating on the part of it that he does not like.

SPEECH.PARA: The letter states:
Response to criticisms:
(a) She acknowledges she should not have participated in the urine substitution. Maurie Plant was the Team Manager; she had known and respected him; he had helped her in the sport . . .
I do not regard that as an irrelevance. I do not regard it as one line, either. It is clearly not that; it is significant. As a result of that the recommendations state:
(a) Ensure that Australian Athletics further investigates Maurie Plant's actions in the urine substitution.
(b) Write to Jane Flemming informing her that Board of the AIS strongly disapproves . . .
(c) Inform all athletes and coaches . . . of the ASC/AIS drug policy . . .

It goes on to say that the athlete will get a life ban if he or she does it again. The recommendations go far enough. The Commission has responded to criticisms. I do not accept all that is in its response, but I do not believe-and I did not believe at the time-that those responses to criticisms amount to some total justification for the penalty that is given. As an example, nowhere in the response to criticisms is it stated that at the time the incident occurred in 1986 the Australian Institute of Sport and the Australian Sports Commission did not have a drug policy as they do now. That is not even stated in response to criticisms, and yet there is no question that that is an important part of the justification for the penalty that was given. It is a very important, crucial part, which is not even in the response to criticisms. Senator Crichton-Browne should not keep harping on this response to criticisms as if it were the justification that it clearly is not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am convinced, and I shall remain convinced, that a reasonable reading of that document draws one inexorably to that conclusion. I am satisfied that that is also the Minister's belief. I have no doubt that is the reason why he wrote these prophetic words:

SPEECH.PARA: I may well be called upon to defend the actions of the Commission in response to the interim report and would appreciate your assistance in ensuring that I am able to do so convincingly.

The tragedy is that Harris wrote back, gave the Minister a mouthful of cheek, and left him where is is now. The Minister was smart enough and wise enough to know what was going to happen. Harris responded to the Minister, stating:

We are both at a loss to understand your statement: `Your report of the interviews conducted by yourself and the Deputy Chairman does not make clear that a thorough investigation of the allegations listed during the enquiry has been carried out'.
Those are the Minister's words. Quite frankly, they are logical words.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am glad you said my words.

—They are good words and logical words. That is where I am-I am where the Minister is. That is why I would have written and said what the Minister has said: `Hey, Mr Harris, I am going to have to wear this in the Senate some time. It is a pretty inadequate report-it tells me absolutely nothing. Jane Flemming explains that she is 21, white, female; first trip overseas; didn't like the Committee; disturbed by her appearance before it, went across to give somebody else a serve and copped one herself by accident on the way past; and the following recommendations flow from it'. No wonder the Minister wrote back to the Commission. I thought that Senator Richardson might have taken the opportunity now to restate what he restated in that letter; that is, it is totally unsatisfactory. Mr Harris wrote the Minister a pompous letter simply saying that he was steeped in either ignorance or stupidity and that he did not understand what he was on about. I ask: Would the Minister please explain to me the substance of any subsequent knowledge that he has received from the Commission that satisfied him that a complete and thorough inquiry has taken place.

—As a result of the correspondence that I had received from Mr Harris, I was not satisfied that a thorough investigation had taken place. Because of that I spoke to him about the incident. I was satisfied after that conversation that the interviews which he and Mr Coates had conducted were thorough-very thorough. Once I was satisfied that that process had taken place properly, I did not believe, and do not believe, that it was my place to second guess the penalties which the Commission had decided were appropriate for those who had been interviewed.
—What processes took place which now satisfy the Minister? What new information now satisfies him that a full inquiry took place?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was satisfied that the interviews which were conducted by Mr Harris were satisfactory. Let us remember that Ted Harris is, indeed, an eminent Australian, not only with an impressive record in business but also with an extraordinary record in serving Australia in honorary capacities in a whole range of ways. We could perhaps regard Mr Coates as the foremost sporting official in the country. They are not two lightweights who do not have a clue. They are two very respected and very experienced people.

SPEECH.PARA: When I spoke to Mr Harris, I was satisfied that the interviews that he and Mr Coates had conducted were thorough; that every question that could possibly be asked was asked; that the athletes and coaches concerned were, if you like, grilled adequately; and that every opportunity had been taken to maximise the information that could have been gleaned from an investigation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do I take it that, as a result of a telephone conversation with Mr Harris, the Minister was satisfied that a full investigation had taken place and no further action was required. The Minister made a phone call and Mr Harris said `Hey Richo, it is all okay'. If not, what did he say?

—I do not think he said, `Richo, it is all okay', and I do not think I said, `Oh good Ted, that will do me'. I think it was a little different to that. I would not pretend to be able to remember the exact words that were used.
—Give it your best shot.

—I think I would do all of us a disservice if I attempted to do that. My memory is not that good, but I can remember the tone of the conversation, the tenor of it, if you like, and I think it could be said to have had its difficult moments.
—The conversation?

—Yes, the conversation. It was not a short conversation; it was lengthy. In fact, I think I had a number of conversations with Mr Harris about it. I do not think there was only one telephone conversation; I remember seeing him one day about it.
—But in the end it went nowhere.

—It is not a question of going nowhere. I discussed with him the depth of the interviews that he and Mr Coates had conducted with the athletes and coaches concerned, and I was satisfied that they were indeed deep and had covered all the ground that they needed to cover.

—I take it that the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson) is now saying that the content of the report of the Committee for the Environment, Recreation and the Arts in no way relates to the recommendations?

—I do not think I can say that it in no way relates to the recommendations. I have simply pointed out to Senator Crichton-Browne several times that I do not regard the heading `Response to criticism' as equalling justification for decision.
—Why put it in?

—Because they thought they had a point to make, and the correspondence makes it very obvious that some members of the Commission felt aggrieved by the way in which the Committee for the Environment, Recreation and the Arts had conducted itself and by some of the conclusions that had been reached in the interim report, and they are reacting somewhat angrily on occasions to those concerns. I am not about to censor them and tell them that they cannot do that. I do not believe that `Response to criticisms' equals justification for decision. I have pointed out that certainly one of the main justifications for the decision in the Flemming case is not included in `Response to criticisms' because there is no criticism being made of it. So I just do not understand how Senator Crichton-Browne can continue to try to equate the two terms.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have clearly been misled. I thought this was a report and response by the Australian Sports Commission to the Government on the drugs in sport inquiry held by the Standing Committee for the Environment, Recreation and the Arts. The Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson) is now telling me that it is not a sophisticated, elegant and detailed response to the Committee's findings but a bit of a bitch about what the athletes thought. So it is a substitute for explaining to the Government, the Committee of the Whole and the wider Australian community how they drew the conclusions they did in respect of the recommendations.

SPEECH.PARA: What the Minister is telling me is that he has had a phone call but that so far the Australian Sports Commission has not submitted a written report to him which explains, justifies or clarifies the recommendations that it made. I was misled because I took this to be its response to the inquiry. The Minister is telling me that in fact it is not; it is something quite different. If it is, are we able to obtain from the Commission detailed grounds for the conclusions that it arrived at if they are thus far not recorded in this report?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not believe that the Commission, in writing this correspondence, attempted to respond to the interim report.
—Do they propose to?

—I do not think it is a matter of the Commission responding. In the end it will be a case of the Government responding. Whether the Commission wishes to respond or not I have not ascertained, but I will. The Government will have to respond. No doubt in the Government responding it would take into account the views expressed by the Commission.

SPEECH.PARA: In so far as this document is concerned I think Senator Crichton-Browne is missing a fairly important point. In the letter that I sent to Mr Harris I did not criticise the recommendations. At no point, so far as I can recall, have I said that they are inadequate. I will have another read of the letter I wrote to him. I certainly did not criticise the recommendations. I criticised at some length the adequacy of the investigation.

All I am saying, and have been trying to say for two hours, is that I am satisfied that as a result of the inquiries I have made the Commission thoroughly investigate those allegations and the recommendations it subsequently came to were based on that thorough investigation. I did not ask for a justification of the recommendations. I was concerned to make sure that a proper investigation had been conducted and I am now satisfied that that is the case.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would have thought that an independent commission, very substantially funded by taxpayers' money, which is indirectly subject to very considerable criticism by a standing committee of the Senate, has an obligation not only to Senator Richardson by way of a telephone call but also to the Australian sporting community, the Parliament and to all taxpayers to provide a detailed response to a report of that nature. On the basis of what the Minister has now told me thus far it has not done so. Can I take it that the Minister was indicating earlier that he would ask the Commission to provide a detailed report of that nature?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would assume, and I will check this, that the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, Mrs Kelly, in preparing the Government's response to the interim report and to the final report tabled yesterday, would talk to the Commission to seek its input. I am certain that that would take place. As to the actual progress of that consultation, I do not know. I can give the Senate a guarantee that the views of the Commission would at least form part of the Government's response so it will certainly be asked to comment on the two documents. I am sure that Mrs Kelly will use appropriate judgment as to how much of that the Government ought to agree with or include directly in its own response.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the Minister now have a response to my question as to whether boxing could be described as being in a high-risk category in relation to a survey of drug use in Australian sport?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a response to Senator Crichton-Browne's question. The survey of drug use in Australian sport carried out during 1979 to 1982 on behalf of the Australian Sports Medicine Federation was aimed at determining the nature and extent of drug use by Australian sports men and women. Individual sports people in a wide range of sports that were popular in Australia recorded the drugs they had used in connection with their own sporting activity. The final sample on which the analysis was based consisted of 4,064 completed and returned questionnaires from 31 different sports. Generally, there was representation from each State in which the separate sports were popular. There was representative sampling of competitors of each sex, of all age groups and of professional and amateur sports people.

SPEECH.PARA: The results for boxing shown against the identifiable categories of drugs, which respondents had to state whether they had used directly in connection with their sporting activities, were: 35.3 per cent of respondents who were boxers had used vitamin and food supplements; none had used anti-inflamatory drugs for sporting injuries; 11.8 per cent responded on pain-relieving drugs, 17.6 per cent on drugs for asthma and nasal congestion, one per cent on drugs to reduce body weight; and suggesting that they had used anabolic steroids, stimulants, sedatives or tranquillisers. The total sample size for boxers was 17.
Progress reported.
