The response read as follows-
RESPONSE BY MR A. E. HARRIS A.C.
AGREED TO BY MR HARRIS AND THE COMMITTEE OF PRIVILEGES PURSUANT TO RESOLUTION 5 (7) (b) OF THE SENATE OF 25 FEBRUARY 1988

In the adjournment debate in the Senate on December 19, 1989 (Hansard, page 4847), Senator MacGibbon sought to bring to the attention of the Senate what he regarded as a serious attack on the rights of Senators to perform their duties and to discharge their responsibilities. In doing so, Senator MacGibbon referred to a letter which he had received from me in my capacity as Chairman of Australian Airlines Limited and which he described as `threatening'. I deny any such intention and seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard that letter. The letter read as follows:
October 10, 1989
Senator D. J. MacGibbon
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
My Dear Senator,

My attention has been drawn to remarks made by you in the Senate on October 5 1989. Would you be kind enough to explain to me what you mean by `but we object violently when that change (the need for change within the Civil Aviation Authority) is brought about as a result of political pressure by the Prime Minister looking after his mates, Mr Harris and Sir Peter Abeles and the airlines that they represent.'
The following are the facts, Senator, in respect of Australian Airlines:
1. There has been no pressure whatever placed on the Civil Aviation authority by Australian Airlines.
2. All of the negotiations with the Pilots' Federation were carried out by the management of Australian Airlines under the direction of the Chief Executive Officer, Mr James Strong.
3. All members of the Board were aware of the negotiations and unanimously endorsed the actions of Mr Strong and his management team.
4. At no time during this dispute has the Prime Minister or any member of the Government given a single direction to myself, any board member or any member of the management of the Airlines.

5. The Chief Executive Officer of Australian Airlines, Mr James Strong retired from the Airline on September 24 as had been announced by him some months ago. The Board has retained Mr Strong as a consultant until the dispute with the pilots is resolved.
As you appear to have some particular concern as to my role in the dispute, let me spell it out for you.

As Chairman of the Airline I have, on behalf of the Board been actively involved with our management in seeking, in the initial stages of the dispute, that the negotiations with the AFAP which were most comprehensive, should reach a successful conclusion.

When the AFAP `walked out' of those negotiations and subsequently induced their members to abandon their employment with the Airline, we have endeavoured to employ qualified competent pilots to bring the Airline back to normal operations.
We will continue in the pursuit of this objective.
I look forward to your explanation which I have sought in the opening paragraph of this letter, copy of which I am sending to members of my Board.
Yours sincerely,
A. E. HARRIS
Chairman
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister representing the Attorney-General been drawn to speeches by Sir James Balderstone, Chairman of the Australian Mutual Provident (AMP) Society, and Sir Eric Neal, Chairman of Westpac Banking Corporation, as reported in yesterday's Australian Financial Review, calling for an improvement in business ethics? Do these comments accord with the Government's view? How does the Government propose to improve this unacceptable situation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it was very remarkable, or at least worth commenting on, that the chief of the AMP Society, Sir James Balderstone, took advantage of his address to policyholders to speak of what he saw as a need to establish a national corporate regulatory body to tackle the speedy prosecution of errant directors. In support of that call, he commented on the way in which dishonest directors had not acted in the best interests of their shareholders, but, further, in so doing had acted in a way which undermined confidence of investors both domestically and overseas in business opportunities in the Australian economy.

ANSWER.PARA: I believe that the status in which Sir James Balderstone is quite rightly held adds great weight to the understanding that is growing in the community that one of the key reasons for and purposes and goals in establishing a national corporate regulatory body is, indeed, to enhance the reputation of Australian business in the eyes of investors, particularly those from overseas as we continue to require their investment confidence in order to build up business, commercial and trading live in Australia.

I believe that the support now given by major elements within the business community to the setting up of the Australian Securities Commission is to be welcomed, and I believe it is also to be linked to the clear statements by the proposed Chairman of the Australian Securities Commission, Tony Hartnell, that he intends to take very speedy action in order to enforce the duties of directors and that he will take action against directors who breach their duties. I believe that the type of legal proceedings that might be appropriate could vary between the civil and criminal jurisdictions. But the point is that the courts in Australia will be involved, according to Mr Hartnell, in his attempt to ensure that company directors undertake their fiduciary duties in a way which is required by the law and which enhances the reputation of Australian business both domestically and abroad. I understand that the Senate and House of Representatives committees involved in these areas are looking at the duties of directors and reviewing those duties in a number of different contexts. I believe that those parliamentary reviews will assist this Parliament in ensuring that the law, which we make and seek to have enforced, will indeed ensure that company directors act in the best interests of shareholders and in a way which will enhance the reputation of Australian business.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Is it not the normal practice that decisions as to whether or not the Commonwealth will set up or join in a royal commission are made by Cabinet? Was the decision not to join at this time the royal commission proposed by the New South Wales Government and Parliament a decision of Cabinet or only that of the Acting Prime Minister on the advice of the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs?
—The fact of the matter is that Cabinet has been informed about that, but no decision has been made by Cabinet.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Do I understand that Cabinet has not made any decision in relation to this matter at all; it is just a decision of the Acting Prime Minister? Is that the position?

—As I understand it, the Prime Minister administers the Royal Commissions Act. Without going into history, there would have been earlier decisions made about royal commissions in which preliminary decisions were made, but not by the Cabinet. If the honourable senator refers to the last part of the Acting Prime Minister's letter to the Premier of New South Wales, he will, as I recall it, see that on these issues room is left for negotiations with the New South Wales Government.

—Has the attention of the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health been drawn to a notice under the heading `Urgent Drug Recall'? Is he also aware that Ayerst Laboratories Pty Ltd is recalling two batches of premarin 0.625 milligram 28s because of a labelling error resulting in prednisone 5 milligram tablets being found in two bottles labelled premarin? Can the Minister inform the Senate what medical problems could develop if the wrong tablets were taken? How successful was the recall by Ayerst Laboratories, and what quantity of tablets have been affected by this mix-up? Has any detailed report of this labelling error been sought from Ayerst Laboratories?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister has informed me that he and his Department are aware of the problem with premarin. The Department of Community Services and Health instituted the recall. This involved the immediate issue of a press release to all media outlets, including the ethnic media. At the same time a recording was provided on a 008 number to enable pharmacists to obtain details as soon as they were approached. This facility is made known to pharmacists through the pharmaceutical benefits schedule and is also listed in telephone directories. This action was followed as soon as possible by notices in the press placed by the company concerned.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Jones asked about the medical problems which could develop. They depend, in large part, on the reason the premarin was prescribed. Possible indications for the drug include: post-menopausal oestrogen replacement; hypogenitalism and various forms of cancer. For the most common indication, post-menopause, the intended dose of premarin would be low, so the unintended prednisone dose would be low. The main effect would be onset of uterine bleeding, simulating menstruation, due to cessation of premarin when the patient transferred inadvertently to the wrong tablet.

It is conceivable that a dangerous situation could arise if prolonged high dose premarin had been intended. This could result in a patient taking high doses of prednisone for several weeks. This could aggravate a serious underlying disease, such as diabetes, and could carry the danger of collapse when the prednisone was suddenly stopped. I am advised that the likelihood of such a situation arising is low.

One full bottle from each batch was found. We are waiting for details of the recall as it proceeds. No further faulty bottles have been returned to date. A detailed report of the labelling error has been requested from Ayerst Laboratories. This matter will also be investigated by the Commonwealth goods manufacturing practice inspectorate. While in this a reputable company has behaved properly and responsibly, it is a timely reminder of the need for comprehensive regulations in this area to prevent less responsible operators injuring consumers. Members of the Senate would do well to recall this example when reconsidering the Therapeutic Goods Regulations in the Budget sitting.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Treasurer. When will the Australian Bureau of Statistics be calling tenders for the printing of the census form for the 1991 census of population and housing? How many forms will be printed? Given the recommendation of the Department of Administrative Services that the Commonwealth should `actively promote the use of recycled paper', what decisions have been made to ensure that these forms are printed on recycled paper?

—This is a matter, of course, about which I am not an expert. Senator Bell was kind enough to give me notice of this question. The answer which has been provided to me is that tenders for the printing of the forms for the 1991 census of population and housing were called in December 1989 and the successful tenderer was determined in March of this year. The total number of household and personal forms to be printed for the 1991 census is 11,800,000. With regard to the last part of the question-which I think Senator Bell regards as the most important part of the question-it is not possible to have the census forms printed on recycled paper because the use of optical mark recognition technology for reading information from the completed census form requires precision printing on very high quality paper that cannot be obtained from recycled sources. The information booklet which will be delivered to all households in association with the census and the census form will be printed on recycled paper.

—Can the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade say what the Government's view is regarding the impact on Australia of the single European economic market integration from 1992? Specifically, is there any concern in the Australian Government about a `fortress Europe' developing, which could make it harder for Australia to export to Europe?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have noted a number of recent statements, including one by the shadow Minister for Trade Negotiations, that the post-1992 European Community poses a considerable threat to Australian trade. I think the Australian Government's view generally on the proposed completion of the single European market in 1992 is well-known. We welcome the opportunities for Australian industry which the single market will present in terms of greater economies of scale, wider choice of bases for investment, simpler and cheaper operating rules, and a bigger pool of skilled labour. We are encouraging Australian business firms to take advantage of the new opportunities opened up by the single market.

ANSWER.PARA: Nonetheless, we have had a number of concerns based on our experience with the common agricultural policy (CAP) and coal subsidies that the single market could create a `fortress Europe'. After all, in relation to the CAP and coal, as I have said on a number of public occasions, it is not just a matter of `fortress Europe', it is a matter of the drawbridge being up, bolted and, effectively, the key thrown away. I think it is fair to say that our fears have now largely been allayed in relation to those particular areas of concern-particularly, things like local content regulations, anti-dumping and the application of the principles of reciprocity, which have been key areas of concern over the last couple of years as the 1992 process has evolved. We are, of course, watching the development of the single market very closely and we are assessing its effects sector by sector, issue by issue. We remain concerned generally to break down the fortress area that does still exist with the CAP and coal. Both our bilateral representations and our multilateral negotiations are directed to those ends.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Treasurer, who is responsible for the Australian Statistician, aware that the Statistician has issued proceedings for libel against a member of this chamber? Can the Minister give an unequivocal assurance that no public funds or resources have been, or will be, used by the Statistician for the conduct of this action?
—I have no knowledge of that matter. I will try to obtain an answer for Senator Puplick as soon as possible.

—Has the Minister representing the Treasurer seen the report in Wednesday's Age that Caroline Chisholm, the only woman depicted on our currency, is to be replaced on the $5 note by the Queen? Is the report correct? If so, who made the decision and why? Can the decision be reconsidered?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nobody would dispute the fact that the job of Treasurer in Australia is difficult, but added to the burden of the Australian economy this particular issue makes the job even more horrendous than I would ever have imagined. The attention of the Treasurer has been drawn to the issues raised in Senator Zakharov's question. The design of Australian bank notes is an issue primarily for the Reserve Bank, which consults various experts about the design. The Treasurer does not have a power of veto over the design of notes but is, of course, consulted by the bank about new currency designs. At this stage the bank has suggested that the Queen replace Caroline Chisholm, as Senator Zakharov points out, on the new $5 note to be circulated later this year.

ANSWER.PARA: The next part of this written answer says that this would restore the monarch to the lowest denomination of Australian notes! The monarch has featured on all series of Australian notes since the mid-1920s, and the bank has suggested that this tradition continue. I believe that the bank plans to introduce a fresh set of designs featuring other men and women who have been prominent in Australia's history, as is the custom in most countries when a new series of notes is issued.

Having said that, I am very aware that the Treasurer is concerned about some of the issues raised in Senator Zakharov's question-it has been a matter of public comment and so on-and will be talking further to the Reserve Bank about its plans for the new series of notes, including the $5 note.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have a supplementary question. In the answer that the Minister gave he said that the Reserve Bank consults various people about the design. Whom did the Reserve Bank consult in this case, and were any of them women?
—I will have to take that part of the question on notice. I will obtain an answer as soon as I can.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. Having regard to the fact that the China Steel project involves an investment in a value adding export industry of $2.5 billion and that the Minister indicated in his answer earlier that Malaysia had offered a favourable incentive package to attract the project to that country, and in view of the financial incentives the Government gave Kodak (Australasia) Pty Ltd to remain in Australia, will the Minister outline the efforts taken by the Government to have China Steel establish its project in Australia?

—No, I will not. I have been in fairly regular communications with the chairman of China Steel about this issue-I still am-and I do not think it is appropriate that I reveal the details of those discussions at this point in time.
—What is the reaction of the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce to car registration figures released by the industry analyst, Paxus Information Services (Aust.) Pty Ltd, yesterday?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can only answer from recollection. I did see the Paxus figures a day or two ago. My recollection is that motor vehicle registrations showed a decline of about 13 per cent over the previous announced figures. I think that is consistent with the general downturn in demand in the Australian economy. I guess that the motor vehicle industry statistics in respect of registrations have lagged a bit compared with other industries. However, on the other hand, I think that the figures also show a greater number of registrations in the last month than in the same month of last year.

ANSWER.PARA: I think the figures are a bit equivocal. They show a trend downwards but still show higher performance in terms of sales and registrations by the motor vehicle industry than that of a year ago. I think it is difficult to say in those circumstances whether we can draw any firm conclusions from what is happening other than the ones which I have indicated.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the Minister representing the Attorney-General inform the Senate how much money was wasted by the Commonwealth Government on the High Court of Australia's challenge to the Commonwealth's power to provide for the incorporation of companies which was bought by a number of States, bearing in mind that the Commonwealth is required to pay its own costs and the costs of the States?

—To talk in terms of waste when one is trying to resolve a major constitutional issue is to adopt quite the wrong language. It was recognised right from the first consideration of the legislation in this chamber that certain elements would be postponed and that a High Court challenge was very desirable in order to try to clarify certain matters which have been unclear over the last several decades with regard the the way in which the High Court might interpret the corporations' power. I would not regard any expenditures that might be involved in securing that High Court interpretation as involving waste. In fact, it has clarified matters and now allowed the necessary political negotiations to continue in a way in which I believe will be extremely fruitful and beneficial to the Australian nation.

—Mr President, I have a supplementary question. Will the Minister please answer the question and advise the Senate of what the cost of that High Court case was, and obviously the cost of the Commonwealth's share and the State's share?
—It is a different question, not a supplementary question, but I will certainly seek what information I can for the honourable senator.

—My question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade relates to the declaration of independence in Bougainville last week. Is the Minister able to advise whether or not the safety of Australian citizens still residing on Bougainville is under threat as a result of the continuing instability on the island? Is it possible to determine the consequences for those Australian residents on Bougainville of Australia's refusal to recognise the claim of republic status for Bougainville?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —At present there are 11 Australians on Bougainville. The High Commission in Port Moresby had been in contact with them up until the cutting of all telecommunication links to Bougainville on 17 May. The High Commission will continue to maintain contact as best it can under the current very difficult circumstances. It must be accepted, however, that Australians remaining on Bougainville face risk from the continuing instability there. We have no reason at this time to believe that this risk has been increased by Australia's refusal to acknowledge the Bougainville Revolutionary Army's claim to declare independence.

ANSWER.PARA: Throughout the Bougainville crisis the Government has been determined to ensure the welfare of the Australians on the island. We maintained a consular presence there until shortly after the withdrawal of Papua New Guinea security forces in March. On 25 January and again on 5 February this year my Department issued consular notices advising all Australians to leave, if their presence was not essential. I lost no opportunity to reinforce that advice in my own statements. A further notice was issued on 15 March urging all Australians to leave. Since the issue of that first consular notice 840 Australians have left the island.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services. I draw the Senate's attention to an article in the Melbourne Herald on Monday, 21 May referring to a letter sent by the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services, Mr Peter Staples, to his Federal electorate assembly. I will quote from the letter he wrote, a copy of which I have obtained. He said:

QUESTION.PARA: I am no longer Minister for Housing and Aged Care-`roofs and wrinkles'-but Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services, which has been dubbed-`wrinkles, runts and remedies'.
I seek leave to table a copy of the Minister's letter.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you want to incorporate it?
—No, I seek leave to table it.

—Given the comments by the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services in his letter, and the Prime Minister's remarks in September of last year when he referred to an aged pensioner as a `silly old bugger', can the Minister tell the Senate whether these derogatory comments are indicative of the Government's attitude to our senior citizens? I also ask what action will be taken against the Minister, Mr Staples, given the call by the Nursing Homes Association of Victoria for his resignation? Will he at least be asked to apologise to the relevant sections of the community for his insulting remarks?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not have the letter in front of me but, as I heard the particular paragraph, it seemed that Mr Staples was not speaking directly but rather indicating that certain persons referred to the groups in the terms that Senator Patterson outlined. I understand-anybody who knows Mr Staples would agree-that nobody has tried harder to provide a very widespread range of services to assist those who might otherwise be without shelter or proper care, particularly among the frail aged. For example, only last Saturday, in Kingston, south of Hobart, I opened an elderly persons' hostel on behalf of the Christian communities in Kingston. They expressed their delight at the support that the Federal Government-through Mr Staples-was giving to aged people in the provision of a wide range of nursing home, community care and hostel-type accommodation in order to make Australia a much more civilised society, as indicated by the way in which we care for our frail and aged citizens.

ANSWER.PARA: I believe it is quite clear from the Minister's record that the remarks in no way indicate any lack of resolve, compassion or practical care on his part to ensure that through his portfolio he delivers services to all those groups within his care in a way which ensures that Australia is a more civilised society. Those who receive the benefit of the programs administered by the Minister would be the first to acknowledge that fact.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. What steps has the Government taken to prevent a major oil spill in the Great Barrier Reef? In particular, has the Government taken steps to require the piloting of ships through the reef, which is acknowledged to be amongst the most dangerous passages in the world? On what basis does the Government impose other controls for the protection of the reef under the World Heritage Commission? Will the Government consider using its powers to control access to Australian ports as a means of ensuring that foreign ships accept piloting when passing through the reef? Finally, does the Minister agree that the Barrier Reef contingency plan for oil spills, known as `Reefplan', is inadequate to cope with spills on the reef north of Cairns; if so, what action will the Minister take to address the inadequacies?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last year I attended a meeting of a Ministerial Council between Queensland and the Commonwealth at which the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority made a presentation on `Reefplan'. Obviously, any plan that protects a couple of thousand miles of reefs is always going to be difficult to administer. But with `Reefplan' the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority has made a pretty valiant attempt to control damage, should it occur. There have been only a couple of very minor spills on the Great Barrier Reef, despite a great amount of increased shipping traffic. Thus far, it has not been necessary for `Reefplan' to be put into action to solve any great emergency.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Dunn should also bear in mind that the reaction of oil in the very warm waters of the Great Barrier Reef presents less of a problem than does oil in Arctic or Antarctic waters, where we have seen some disasters in recent times. Nonetheless, obviously if we were to get a major spill we would be presented with a major problem.

The Authority has paid particular attention to spills north of Cairns. The recent spill that took place there was monitored very carefully and the Authority was satisfied that no lasting damage occurred. I think I saw a report on that while I was still the Minister and I was certainly satisfied when I read it. Overall I am satisfied that Reefplan is about as far as the Great Barrier Reef Authority could possibly go.

Over the past couple of years we have been looking at the question of pilotage of ships through the Barrier Reef and discussions are continuing with the Queensland Government on what might occur. I will have to check for Senator Dunn on where it is at the moment, but my recollection is that no decision has yet been made to make pilotage compulsory. I think that has probably been done on two bases-one being cost and the other the fact that thus far we have managed to avoid any major disaster and therefore there is some evidence that the system works.

Nonetheless, the potential for an oil spill and the damage it could cause is so great that I have the matter still under review. I do not believe that at this stage we have ever ruled out getting compulsory pilotage if we can get agreement from Queensland. Discussions with the Queensland Government will continue and I shall attempt between now and Monday to find out exactly where they are up to.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer to reports that today President Bush has said that the United States is `reviewing its whole policy on Cambodia'. What information does the Australian Government have about the nature of that review? Will any review of the American policy assist or hinder Australia's own diplomatic efforts with regard to achieving a settlement in Cambodia? Finally, is not the United States still committed to the efforts of the five permanent members of the United Nations Security Council to promote a settlement, not least by the meeting of this group in New York tomorrow?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My understanding is certainly that the US is committed to the permanent five process, that there are a substantial number of United States inputs into that process in respect of which we have been in consultation with the US. The commitment is still unequivocally there to a comprehensive settlement essentially employing the kind of strategy that Australia mapped out in our contribution to this process, beginning last November. I think any reference to a review of US policy by President Bush should not be taken as signalling any kind of sea change at all in that process. It is essentially a matter of riding with what is a fast developing situation and adjusting policy response accordingly as things move along.

ANSWER.PARA: There is a lot happening at the moment and it is a little difficult for me to be more precise than that. Certainly there are some encouraging signs that the ice floes are breaking up a little at all three levels. Things are happening at the level of the P5 or Permanent Five-that is, the major powers whose continuing patronage of internal parties has been such a crucial factor in keeping the conflict going. Things are happening at a regional level, with Thailand, Japan, ourselves and others all being very active in trying to craft ways through the present impasses. The Cambodian parties themselves are showing a willingness to talk to each other and to try to craft effective solutions.

Hopefully, some of that will come to fruition in the meeting still scheduled to take place in Tokyo in early June. I am not certain what particular significance is to be attributed to the language to which Senator Teague refers but all the available evidence is that a path has been set, and there is no particular reason to assume any dramatic or imminent deviation from that path so far as the US is concerned.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the Minister for Social Security give the Senate updated information about the progress of the child support scheme?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think there has been some criticism of the child support scheme in recent times, particularly because of some delays that have been occurring from the date of application through to the date when maintenance can actually flow. Certainly we have experienced some difficulties. It will be appreciated, of course, that the scheme is actually administered not by my Department but by the Australian Taxation Office. In the course of the next week or two I think we will be in a position to announce that some very significant extra resources are about to be put into the Child Support Agency so that we might eliminate some of those delays. Nonetheless, despite the fact that there have been some delays, it should be noted that 17,500 payments were made in the month of March, which suggests that, even with the difficulties I have just outlined, the scheme has had some extraordinary success.

ANSWER.PARA: At the moment there is a difference, understandably, between those who are receiving payments under stage 1 of this scheme as opposed to those who are under stage 2. There is a difference between the average amounts that have been received under stage 2, which is about $69 a week, and the average for stage 1, which is about $56 a week, and that affects those who came into the first part of the scheme. Nonetheless, that difference appears to be narrowing. There is a general indication that the value of court orders is continuing to rise, which is something which we should all be grateful for.

About 81 per cent of non-custodial parents whose liabilities are collected by the Agency now meet their maintenance obligations in part or in full. This suggests, of course, that there are still some cases of recalcitrant people who do not live up to their obligations and we are certainly continuing our efforts to pursue them to make sure that they contribute properly.

In terms of looking at the profile of those who are in receipt of these payments through the Agency, it should be noted that there is a total of 245,000 sole parent pensioners in Australia at the moment. Six per cent of them receive payments through the Child Support Agency, a further 30 per cent receive their maintenance privately and another 12 per cent are waiting for processing and collection by the CSA-making a total of 48 per cent of sole parent pensioners. It is certainly an encouraging result, given the length of time that this scheme has been in operation.

If Senator Giles is concerned why the number is not higher, it should be noted that 30 per cent of the pre-scheme pensioners do not have to take action under that child support scheme; about 13 per cent are new applicants with exemptions-obviously, widows come into that category, but so do those for whom pursuit of an order would require them to risk violence and, sadly, there are too many of those cases; and the remainder, which is some 8 to 10 per cent, is made up of those who are yet to obtain court orders-some of whom have had applications rejected by the Agency because information has not been sufficient or has not been supplied.

So I think if one reviews the work of the scheme to date, and certainly it has been a major advance for those who have not received maintenance in the past, one will see that it has improved collection and that it has even had the effect of gradually forcing up court orders so that children can receive more adequate payments and we can ensure that their lot is made just that little bit easier.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question to the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health concerns the availability to Medicare patients of magnetic resonance imaging which is used to test for the presence of tumours. Can the Minister advise to what extent this procedure is superior to computerised axial tomogram or CAT scanning? Is it the case that this procedure is available at only one public hospital in New South Wales and not in the Australian Capital Territory, and that the waiting list for the test is approximately eight weeks? If so, can the Minister indicate whether the Government is considering making this procedure more widely available, within a reasonable time, to Medicare patients?

—I am afraid that I am not in a position to offer the medical opinions which Senator Reid seeks, nor do I know some of the other details that she requires. I will ask the Minister for Community Services and Health to provide her with an answer as speedily as possible.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. The Minister has frequently stated that Australia has the toughest ozone protection legislation in the world. Is it not the case that the existing legislation which was passed in March last year merely implements the Montreal Protocol, to which many other nations have given effect, but does allow for tougher control by regulation under part V of the Ozone Protection Act? Why have we not seen regulations under part V? When will we see regulations under part V of that Act?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot recall off the top of my head whether it is part V of the Act or not, but I will check it for Senator Coulter. I have continually made the statement-because it is true-that Australia has gone further in taking steps against ozone depleting substances than any country in the world. In the talks which are taking place in Paris, I think this month-again I will have to check that, but I think it is this month-we are advocating a much strengthened protocol which would take into account the steps we have taken here in Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: I can recall some disagreements with Senator Coulter at the time that we brought the legislation in. He wanted legislation that was even tougher. The Australian Government took the view, I think rightly-and I might say it was supported by the Opposition-that we were about setting levels that were achievable. That is why we set about the process of talking to industry. We had very lengthy talks with industry about this. The fact that we have persuaded our industry to go further than in any country in the world and by 1995, to all intents and purposes, we will have eliminated the offending substances and their use in Australia-except for very small applications, particularly medical ones-suggests to me that if industry can wear it here, it can wear it around the world. We are using the fact that we have made those agreements with industry to convince other governments to take the protocol further.

I am very confident indeed that the Opposition will see a much strengthened protocol in the course of the next 12 months. Australia will be able to take a large share of the credit for the rest of the world at last starting to catch up with us.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. I am certainly heartened to hear the Minister say that the Montreal Protocol may be strengthened on the basis of approaches made by Australia. But the Minister is avoiding the substance of my question. He would be aware that all the parts of that legislation were under the head of power dealing with international obligations and therefore did not go beyond the Montreal Protocol, and that the parts which went further than the Montreal Protocol were put deliberately into part V. They came into the corporations head of power. The Government can move further only if it uses that part, and it requires the passage of legislation. The question is: when are we going to see regulations which mandate that Australia will move further than the existing Montreal Protocol?

—I was not seeking to avoid that part of the question. I will check with the Minister on the progress of the regulations. I simply point out to Senator Coulter and the Senate that we have the agreement of all the States, we have the agreement of business, and the targets we have set are being met all around Australia. There has been no attempt, so far as I am aware, by anyone to get around them. We have managed to get agreement and we are proceeding on that basis. As to the actual promulgation of regulations, I will check with the Minister on the timetable of that and let Senator Coulter know on Monday.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer him to the Treasurer's tardy rejection of the Australia and New Zealand Banking Group Ltd's takeover of the National Mutual Royal Bank, and the ANZ's obligation to offer Royal Bank back to National Mutual. Has the Treasurer considered allowing National Mutual a period of grace to hold Royal Bank pending National Mutual's going through the process of demutualisation and thereby keeping some stability in Royal Bank's operations?
—I have no information which would enable me to answer that question, but I will get it as soon as I can and provide it to Senator Panizza.

—Has the Minister for Defence seen a variety of recent media reports referring to incidents that are reported to have happened in England where numbers of Australian troops are said to have behaved in an unseemly manner? Have those reports been investigated? If so, can the Minister inform the Senate as to their accuracy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Naturally, the Australian defence forces are at all times expected to behave with the proper degree of decorum, especially on exchange visits. It is also true-it is not restricted to the defence forces-that overseas travellers from time to time exhibit a degree of exuberance. Now that they have returned to Australia certain checks will be made. If any disciplinary action is needed, naturally that will proceed. I would not like Senator McKiernan to be misled by the fact that the British gutter press, as usual, will exaggerate any incident that ever occurs.

ANSWER.PARA: The yellow press made a variety of allegations, including one that 80 goldfish were eaten. Honourable senators who have ever suffered waiting for service in a British hotel or the quality of the food that they subsequently got, would not be surprised if certain Australian soldiers had availed themselves of the sushi bar at the back of the hotel, though I am assured that none of them asked for chips and salt to accompany the entree! I think that many of those things were exaggerated. These days, especially following the Australian cricket tour, there is a fair degree of Aussie bashing going on in England. Four-zip; the English did not like that. I think that in this case a bit of get square is going on.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce: Are recent reports which claim that the number of safety measures on expensive imported motor vehicles will be reduced to bring them under the 50 per cent sales tax threshold accurate? If so, will the measure actively discourage technological advances in all new cars purchased for use on Australian roads? Is the Minister happy that all possible steps are being taken by manufacturers to build in the best possible safety features technology has to offer?

—This question has been raised in different forms, particularly relating to the price of both imported and locally built motor vehicles. I will deal with the latter part of the question first. The price of vehicles, both in Australia and internationally, has increased. They are increasingly sophisticated in terms of technology, particularly technology related to safety. In so far as highly priced motor vehicles imported into Australia are concerned, which is the first part of Senator Walters's question, and whether they are deficient in safety--
—To fit into the price.

—I cannot possibly answer that part of the question. That involves an analysis of the subjective view of various importing companies and overseas companies. The question of motor vehicle safety standards is essentially one for State governments. TALK.START.PARA: —On 21 May Senator Hamer asked me a question about Palestinian refugees. It is a long answer and I seek leave to incorporate it in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows-

I am advised that the Israeli Government position is that there is no right of return within the green line, as the pre-1967 boundary is now called, for Palestinians who left Israel as a result of its creation in 1948
the Israeli Government cites security grounds as the reason
it has also stated that `the only long term solution of the Arab refugee question is the resettlement in the midst of their kin in the Arab countries'.
The Israeli Government does not recognise the right to family reunification
although it has allowed some family reunions on a case-by-case basis
after the 1967 war it allowed 39,000 people who had fled to Jordan to return
a larger number were permitted to return to the occupied territories.
There is no comprehensive mechanism for compensation for property left by Palestinians within the green line.
The Israeli Government has declared its willingness to provide compensation for immovable property, predominantly real estate, left within the green line, but on the following conditions
agreement on compensation would be contingent on peace and/or cessation of the Arab economic blockade
payment would be in relation to Israel's financial capacity
refugees accepting compensation would renounce all claims to a right of return, as well as further financial claims against Israel, and
agreement being reached on reciprocal compensation for Jewish property left in Arab countries.

All property left within the green line has reverted to the holdings of the state of Israel, under the authority of the custodian of absentee property and provided for by the absentees property law of 1950. Absentee Palestinian owners have no right to sale or use of the property thus administered.

A right to return and a right to compensation for loss of property for Palestinian refugees is referred to in paragraph 11 of UN General Assembly resolution 194 of 11 December 1948 in the following terms

`The refugees wishing to return to their homes and live at peace with their neighbours should be permitted to do so at the earliest practicable date, and . . . compensation should be paid for the property of those choosing not to return and for the loss of or damage to property which, under the principles of international law or in equity, should be made good by the governments or authorities responsible'.

Although General Assembly resolutions are not of themselves binding instruments in international law they can be reflective of law and help crystallise customary international law. Australia voted in favour of resolution 194 in 1948. All the Arab states voted against.

Australia accepts as a matter of international law that `everyone has the right to leave any country including his own and return to his country' (article 13 (2) of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights

We also accept that `no one shall be subject to arbitrary interference with his . . . home' and that `everyone has the right to protection of the law against such interference or attacks' (article 12 of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights).

It is open to any person inside or outside a country to seek redress through the municipal legal system of that country for compensation for property lost and the return of ownership of the property. If municipal remedies are exhausted, in certain circumstances another state may espouse the claim of the individual against the country in which the property was located as a matter of international law (state responsibility). A key condition is that the person seeking redress have the citizenship of the state espousing the claim at the time the claim arises.
From all of the above a number of points stand out
In the 43 years since the partition of Palestine, attitudes on both the Arab and Israeli sides have hardened

it is most unlikely under now conceivable circumstances that Israel would ever allow a wholesale right of return to within the green line for Palestinians displaced from their homes during the 1948 fighting
the conditions Israel places on civil actions by Palestinians seeking compensation are stringent and would seem to depend finally on an Arab/Israeli peace settlement

because of the citizenship condition set out above, it would be very difficult for Palestinians displaced by the fighting to have access to international law procedures in order to make claims for restoration of property or payment of compensation.

In these circumstances Australia's position on the right of return of Palestinians to what is now Israel and on compensation for property lost as a result of the fighting in 1948 is that we regard these as matters for ultimate resolution in the context of a peace settlement, which may involve the creation of an independent Palestinian state.
We continue to urge all parties to the Arab/Israeli dispute to work towards such a settlement.

It is not true that funding for the University of Tasmania has been cut in 1990. Funding for the 1989-1991 triennium was announced in November 1988 and included provision for increased funding for growth for each year of the triennium. No cuts have been made to the previously announced funding for the University.

Higher education funding is provided in the form of a block operating grant for a specified level of student load within the context of an agreed educational profile covering teaching and research activities.

Institutions have the flexibility to determine the most efficient allocation of resources within their profile according to their own priorities. The Commonwealth does not set quotas for individual faculties or courses or determine the distribution of resources and student load between faculties and schools.

The Government recognises the importance of the arts and humanities, as well as the sciences, in the provision of higher education. It is not the Government's intention that institutions should lessen their commitment to the arts, social sciences and humanities, either in teaching or research. Asian Studies have, in fact, been identified as a national priority area for growth.
Institutions are also encouraged to implement and maintain programs and initiatives which are designed to improve opportunities for women in higher education.

In 1990 higher education in Tasmania will receive operating grant funding of $79.1m for a student load of 7745 places, compared with $76.7m in 1988. This includes funding for 150 additional places in 1990 over the 1989 level.
The University did not in fact meet its student load target in 1989 and, based on early estimates of 1990 load, is unlikely to fill the 7745 places for which it is funded in 1990.

There has been little evidence of unmet demand in Tasmania (except in selected areas such as medicine) and year 12 retention in Tasmania is very low. In 1989, Year 12 enrolments grew by only 118 students while the Commonwealth has provided 150 additional places for new students in 1990.
The University of Tasmania is in fact very well-funded compared with other higher education institutions.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased that Senator Richardson has ventured that far forward because, quite frankly, that is not the view that was expressed by the Commission. I refer to an inquest report signed by Mr K. M. Waller, which reads:

SPEECH.PARA: This inquest concerns the death of a young man, MAURICE FERRANTI, who died aged 23 on 21 October, 1989. Mr Ferranti became suddenly and unexpectedly ill at the home of his girl friend. He was taken to Sutherland Hospital where he suffered a cardiac arrest and passed away.
The report then mentions the name of his girlfriend; I will not mention it as it adds nothing to the matter. It continues:

. . . and the deceased had acted responsibly in taking with them to the hospital substances recently ingested by the deceased, and as it transpired it was those very substances which caused his death.

Mr Ferranti was a man who had taken up the sport of body-building, and as the evidence shows, had become quite fanatical about it. Sports like body-building and weight-lifting have become notorious in recent times for the fact that their practitioners frequently take steroids to build muscle and enhance performance in that way. As I have said, who cares who is the best drug-affected athlete? But the desire for success is such that people risk the criticism, and the dangers, associated with drug-taking in order to be thought the best.

Mr Ferranti was one of these. He has clearly been using steroids for a long period of time. The drug builds muscle, but has certain damaging side effects. There are long-term side effects like cancer and liver damage which should put people off taking the substances, but unfortunately Mr Ferranti did not get that far. Steroids increase fluid in the body, and the athletes then ingest diuretics in order to eliminate the fluid, and increase muscle definition. Some diuretics, like Lasix, eliminate both fluid and salts including potassium from the body. The practise is to then take potassium to replace that chemical. However, Mr Ferranti used aldactone as a diuretic, which is ``potassium-sparing'' that is, it retains the potassium.
Again the report mentions the deceased's girlfriend by name, and continues:

. . . at the request of the deceased, purchased potassium tablets for him as he no doubt believed that he had lost that substance through use of his diuretic. Having ingested a large number of the potassium tablets, he suffered in effect potassium poisoning, which led to his physical distress and, finally, cardiac arrest.

The irony was, that Mr Ferranti died on the day of his competition, and if tested, as he should have been had he won, he would have been disqualified because his body contained the steroids which are illegal.

The case is a stark reminder to people that there are great dangers involved in taking drugs to improve performance. They are rightly banned by all sporting organisations. Their long term effects are very serious, as is demonstrated in this case by the fact that already Mr Ferranti was suffering atrophy of the testes, another nasty side effect. He was probably infertile, Dr Duflou said.
The evidence has not clearly established just who provided the steroids-
and that really does not add to it-

However, it was the potassium tablets, able to be purchased without prescription, which were the final agent of death. However, there was no necessity to take these unless the steroids and diuretics had also been taken . . .
The report continues:
Both steroids and diuretics are only available upon doctor's prescription, and it is an offence to deal in them without.

The purpose of this inquest was to warn possible users of the great danger of both short term disaster, and long term illness, which may arise from the use of steroids, diuretics and indeed any substance for the purpose of enhancing sporting performance. Every drug carries with it the possibility of unpleasant and health menacing side effects. No drug should be taken except under medical supervision. The result of misuse in this case has been the loss of a young and promising life, no doubt a very sad blow to his family and friends.
The court expresses its sympathy to the family.

I read that out because I was disturbed to read the substance of a speech given on 21 May 1990 by Mrs Ros Kelly, the present Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. She was quoted as saying:
I'm very wary of the issue of drugs in sport because I think we have really gone a bit overboard.

I went to the trouble to ring the journalist who reported that article; he read his notes to me verbatim and I took them down. Mrs Kelly was not misquoted. In fact, she went on to say some other things which I will not repeat because I think they add to the embarrassment of others and I will save them for another time.

I would have thought that no graver or more irresponsible statement could be made than to have a Minister-not only a Minister but the Minister responsible for sport-address the Australian Olympic Federation and say that she thought we had gone overboard with drugs, given the painful process that the community, sport, institutions, the Government and the Parliament have gone through to extract enough funds to ensure that we have proper testing and that it has a level of integrity.

All the surveys that have been done thus far show an abysmal lack of knowledge, understanding and, not least, awareness of the direct and indirect effects of performance enhancing drugs upon the people who use them. At a time when the Government is proudly boasting of the amount of money it is spending on education, when our Committee and other authorities are desperately seeking ways to inform young people of the risks and the threats involved in the use of drugs, we have a sports Minister who says she thinks we have gone a bit overboard.

She makes much of the fact that there are to be 2,000 tests this year. I have to assume that that is bad advice because there have not been 2,000 tests. One thousand tests are scheduled this year and 2,000 next year. Mrs Kelly went on to say:
. . . so far we have tested 20 positives, but all are subject to appeals.

It really needs to be seen in that light. In other words, while we have got 20 positives, hold your breath; they are all subject to appeals. I could not believe that, so I rang the Minister's office and asked for it to be put in writing. The correspondence, which I do not happen to have with me, says that the Australian Sports Commission has advised the Minister that each of those 20 tests is under appeal. When I sought the names of the 20 who had tested positive-not because I much cared who they were but simply to identify and define who had appealed-I was advised the names were not available because they were subject to appeal.

I can think of nothing more irresponsible than for the Minister to suggest to the community and the Australian Olympic Federation that we have gone too far in our pursuit of rooting out the corruption of drugs in sport. In respect of the report that was tabled yesterday, Mrs Kelly says:
Let's not focus on the individual because too many people will be hurt and the sport will suffer.

Senator Richardson might like to explain that, as Mrs Kelly is his colleague, not mine. But I would have thought that sport does suffer because of the conduct of the few and if they are not exposed and rooted out, sport, in the long term, will continue to suffer.

When Mrs Kelly was being interviewed by the journalist she also said that she hoped we would put all of this behind us and get on with the future. The truth of the matter is that those who ignore history are bound to make the mistakes of the past.

Life has been made a little bit more difficult for us than it need be in terms of seeking to understand how the Australian Institute of Sport could be so incompetent in respect of its drug testing and how it could be so negligent in not knowing that the weighlifters were taking drugs, that the coaches were buying and supplying them and that young athletes were bringing them into the country. That information has been made publicly available through our inquiry for the purposes of ensuring that it does not happen again. Yet we have the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories saying:
I'm very wary of the issues of drugs in sport because I think we have really gone a bit overboard . . . But let's not get totally neurotic.
Senator Richardson might like to explain what the Minister means when she says:
There is no doubt there is a problem in the international sporting arena, particularly in some sports more than others about drug use. But let's not get totally neurotic.

I would like Senator Richardson to explain the level of care, interest and diligence that his Government intends to apply in future to this issue of educating the public about the effects of the use of drugs in sport. He might like to tell me whether, by concerning myself about Ferranti, a 23-year-old young man who died because of drugs, I am neurotic and have gone overboard.

If honourable senators consult Hansard they will see that Mr Blunn replied:
Put forward or accepted?
I then asked, `What was accepted?' Mr Blunn answered:
It was just that there was a difference between the price they put forward and the price we eventually--
I interrupted and asked:
I want to know what the price was for the Icebird.

Mr Moncur confirmed that it was $3.1m to $3.4m. I ask the Minister: What was the original tender price put forward for Icebird? Also, what was the original price put forward for Akademik Federov? If there was a difference in the price it would appear to me-I would like the Minister to answer this-that Icebird's tender was negotiated down. If that is the case, was the tender for the Akademik Federov renegotiated down; if so, what was its price?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will just give some information on this matter generally. After taking account of fuel, overtime and the requirement for a fuel barge on Akademik Federov, the estimated costs of the two vessels were: Icebird, $3.6m to $3.8m for a 120- to a 133-day period, and the Akademik Federov, $3.05m. Despite the potential saving of approximately $500,000 to $800,000 in using the Akademik Federov, the unanimous recommendation of the tender evaluation group, which included two Antarctic Division officers, the Department of Administrative Services representative and a marine surveyor from the Department of Transport and Communications, was to use the Icebird.

SPEECH.PARA: There were some good reasons for making that decision and they included: that the Icebird would be fully under Antarctic Division control, whereas the Akademik Federov offer was based on a shared operation with the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics (USSR) Antarctic program; the Icebird price was in Australian dollars, and the Akademik Federov price was in United States dollars and was subject to a currency variation which is, as honourable senators would agree, hazardous in this day and age; and the Icebird was available for four voyages, while the Akademik Federov offered only three.

There were other concerns about the Akademik Federov, including the development of schedules to meet both the Australian and the USSR programs, and its availability to operate in Mawson Harbour as its length exceeded the tender specification, the additional travel time for the Australian expeditioners, and cultural and social problems associated with joint use of the vessel over long voyages.

The apparent advantages of the Akademik Federov in marine science capability, long-range helicopter availability, and greater icebreaking capabilities were not regarded as significant pluses as marine science would be undertaken on the Aurora Australis. The helicopters are of limited use and the Icebird's icebreaking capability is sufficient for the period of the season for which the vessel is required. So there is a whole range of reasons why the Icebird was preferred.

In terms of the negotiations, I will have to check with the Department on this matter, but, as far as I am aware, Icebird was negotiated down. I do not believe that the Akademik Federov was negotiated down, either because that did not arise or because those involved were not prepared to negotiate down. I do not know, I will have to have that matter checked.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is rather unfortunate that those involved with the Akademik Federov were not given the opportunity to renegotiate. I note the answer by the Minister that the long-range helicopters from Akademik Federov were not of much use.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer the Minister to the five-year transport plan that I received a couple of days ago with the compliments of the Director. I was promised it last year, and I think it was an oversight that I did not receive it. It seems to me, having read it briefly, that one of the major parts of this particular report, and the whole concept of using air transport as a subsidiary to sea transport, is based around the use of long-range helicopters and Twin Otters. The recommendation in the transport plan was that any intracontinental transport system be based on the use of three long- range helicopters, with the option of using two helicopters and one Twin Otter.

In the Estimates Committee hearing the other day I referred to the fact that the Minister travelled to Russia with Mr Blunn and had negotiations with the Russians on their cooperation in Antarctica. I also referred to the fact that Premier Ryzhkov visited here this year and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) was so impressed that we managed to put out a stamp depicting the cooperation between Russia and Australia in Antarctica. Given the fact that the Akademik Federov is probably one of the most up-to-date icebreaking vessels in the world and, particularly given the fact that the Russians were going to throw in the use of long range helicopters for virtually nothing, we could have at least tested it out, as was envisaged in this transport plan, at far less cost. It was admitted to me in the Estimates Committee hearing that the difference in price between Akademik Federov and Icebird was $800,000. At the end of the day, the only reason I could gather for our not accepting Akademik Federov rather than Icebird was the fact that Australia had full control over Icebird whereas the Akademik Federov involved a joint venture. Even allowing for that, I would have thought the opportunity to mix with the Russian scientists, to observe their methods, and all the other things that go with it, for one season, would have been of tremendous advantage to Australia.

The ice runway plan has fallen through. I will not use the word `failure' in relation to it because I do not think that the Director would accept that word, but it seems to me that it was a futile effort to establish an ice runway. I thought it would have been an ideal opportunity to use long-range helicopters to see how the whole operation could have been used in the future. I do not expect the Minister to comment on that because he has already given me the answer-unless he has anything to add.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be brief. When we were looking at the ice runway plan in the first place, the proposal was to use Hercules aircraft from Australia and then, base-to-base, onshore-never going offshore-use long-range helicopters. In any event, that plan fell by the wayside. It was decided that it would be much more efficient to use fixed wing Twin Otters. So we were not going to use long-range helicopters, anyway. That was further compounded by the fact that this offer involved a ship-to-shore operation-not base-to-base-which was not going to be of any use to us. The marine research capability did not matter because we have the Aurora Australis coming on-stream. We have just spent an enormous amount of money making sure we have the right ship for Australia's purposes, built in Australia and crewed by Australians. We would be crazy not to use it to its fullest. That would have been a waste of money on Australia's part. There is already considerable cooperation between Australia and scientists from the Soviet Union in the Antarctic, and that will continue. It is in no way affected by this decision.

SPEECH.PARA: Obviously, the Antarctic Division, when it is looking at the use of millions of dollars of taxpayers' money, has to look at its most efficient use. There are more voyages, and they are under Australian control. That seems to me to be a tremendous improvement, particularly when we have to query the capacity of the Akademik Federov to operate in Mawson harbour. Of course, additional travel time for all Australian expeditioners would result because the vessel would have been calling in at other places, quite apart from the ones that were required by us. There are a whole range of reasons for the decision. I doubt very much that the Antarctic Division or, indeed, the evaluation group, would have had any other choice but to opt for the Icebird.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I understand it, the currency variations are responsible for the difference. I am not aware of us shaving any corners when it comes to safety. I am sure we would not do that. But I will certainly have that checked and take the rest of the question on notice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.
