TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak for a few minutes this afternoon on the report of the Standing Committee of Privileges presented by Senator Giles earlier today which details a response by Mr A. Harris, the Chairman of Australian Airlines Ltd and the Chairman of the Australian Sports Commission. This is a further stage in what is now becoming a rather tedious exercise on the part of Mr Harris. It is a quite proper use of the parliamentary procedures, particularly the procedures of the Senate, that Mr Harris should seek to put a point of view before the Senate in this way, but implied in the provision for a response such as this to be made is the clear implication that, if the facility is to be used, there has to be some justification for the Senate's time, particularly the time of the Privileges Committee, being taken up in this way.

SPEECH.PARA: In the response provided by Mr Harris today he does nothing at all to justify the use of the Senate's time, least of all to counter the charges made against him by me earlier. I wonder about Mr Harris's judgment when he embarks on this view. I view his response with some gravity, particularly because it does not address the points that I raised initially. The report of Mr Harris certainly merits far more time than the five or ten minutes I will take this afternoon to deal with it.

At the heart of the matter is the right of freedom of speech of members in this Parliament. I hold this right of freedom of speech very dearly. I will support anyone, on any side of the chamber, to not see their rights impaired in any way at all. It is a right that derives from the Parliamentary Act 1987. This, in turn, derives its power from section 49 of the Australian Constitution. It goes back through the House of Commons and the British Parliament, right back to the original Bill of Rights. It is a very cherished position that members of parliament hold.

As one of the longest serving senators in this Parliament I have been involved in all the controversies that have come before us in the last 12 years. I have taken my part in those debates. I have never had anyone write to me the way Mr Harris wrote to me during the pilots dispute. I have never had a letter like that, let alone three letters. Again, it is Mr Harris's right to do so, but I very much question the intention behind writing those letters because the charge that I made against Mr Harris was that he set out quite clearly to intimidate and to bully me and to force me into silence. Of course, he failed.

The origins of this exercise this afternoon lie in the pilots dispute last year. Mr Harris's involvement came about because he is the Chairman of Australian Airlines. I served on the two Senate committees which dealt with the pilots dispute-the original Estimates Committee, which went into the procedures that were followed by the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) in granting air operator certificates and licence validations for overseas aircrew and the general conduct of that Authority through the pilots dispute, and the Select Committee into Certain Aspects of the Airline Pilots' Dispute.
I also spoke on the matter in the chamber whenever it was opportune to do so during, for example, matters of public importance. So I had a central part in it.

As a consequence of that I received three letters: two written to me, the third one to the Chairman of the Committee of Privileges, and all were widely distributed. The intention of all three letters was clearly to intimidate me and force me into silence. It is a matter of history that it had no effect whatsoever nor will it have any effect. I made no response to those letters for two reasons. The first was that I viewed them as beneath contempt and, secondly, they were clearly provocative. After the third one I was forced to respond, which I did on 19 December 1989. In a very measured and moderate way I answered the charges raised by Mr Harris in those letters. That should have ended the matter.

Let me now deal with the purpose of the twenty-third report of the Privileges Committee. As I said at the outset, Mr Harris has every entitlement to put his view-and I do not question that at all, nor do I question the actions of the Privileges Committee. I believe the report of the Privileges Committee is a very proper and correct report and no blame at all attaches to its members for the situation that they were put in. The first point in Mr Harris's response is to claim that:
Senator MacGibbon sought to bring to the attention of the Senate what he regarded as a serious attack on the rights of Senators to perform their duties and to discharge their responsibilities.

Mr Harris tries to assert that it was not a very serious dispute. Mr Harris quotes from his first letter. He does not quote from the second letter, nor from the third. It is a very selective use. I believe that one could argue the case from the first letter that it was possible to come to the conclusion that Mr Harris was not out to intimidate me although I took it to be so at the time, and still do. I was proved correct in my judgment of that by the subsequent letters that arrived. He was very selective in not quoting from the second letter. The second letter ends with the statement:

Unless you advise that you were incorrectly reported in the press or you are able to substantiate any of the allegations you have made, which are requested by return facsimile, the Board seeks an immediate retraction of your comments in the next session of the public inquiry.

That reflects the whole tone of the letter. For the record, let me say that I view all three letters very seriously as an attempt to influence me and to suppress my comments within this Parliament on matters that are properly within my preserve in the public community.

The second point raised in Mr Harris's response is the fact that Australian Airlines exerted no pressure on the Civil Aviation Authority. I do not really want to argue the case as I did before but I do want to say that it was clearly shown before the Committee at the time that one of the major airlines influenced the CAA very clearly-and I believe improperly-with respect to the granting of licences to some French aircrew. That was proved beyond dispute. It also became transparently obvious that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), who made no secret of his direct involvement, was talking with his very old friend Sir Peter Abeles and his other very old friend Mr A. E. Harris continually throughout the dispute. In short, all three major players knew what was happening at all times.

The next important point in Mr Harris's comment relates to an abridged reference to the second letter which is not quoted. In that letter Mr Harris is clearly fencing with words when he said that he had no part in the preparation and dispatch of that letter, that it came from the Board of Australian Airlines.

I accept that literally as being true, but I also accept that it means absolutely nothing. Mr Harris is Chairman of the Board. Mr Harris knew exactly what the resolution of the Board was and almost certainly proposed that I be written to in this intimidatory way by the Board. If he did not propose it, he had one of his friends on the Board propose it. Clearly, he took part in the debate and did not oppose it. Had he opposed it, it would not have gone out. His disclaimer that he took no part in the preparation or dispatch of it is misleading and, in my judgment, quite dishonest.

There is another point of dishonesty in Mr Harris's second letter. He attacked me in that second letter for making derogatory comments about his director of operations-a Mr David Wiltshire. I said nothing about Mr Wiltshire, as the Hansard record showed. In Mr Harris's third letter, he tacitly conceded that that was so because he then attacked my colleague Senator Brownhill for making the statements. However, he did not have the courtesy or good manners to apologise. That was his second act of dishonesty in this matter.

Mr Harris dealt with the matter of Senator Puplick that I referred to in my speech on the adjournment that night in December. That is very revealing of Mr Harris's view on life because he made no apology and there was no sign of remorse in his statement to the Privileges Committee about what he said about Senator Puplick. Mr Harris said:
I categorically deny that I have at any time, or on that occasion, behaved other than as befits the holder of a public office seeking to properly address issues which might have been raised.

The issue that Senator Puplick raised was the fact that he was attacked by Mr Harris because he dared to question one of the representatives of the Australian Sports Commission before an Estimates committee. Mr Harris's response to that was to write to Senator Puplick and Mr Valder, who was then the Federal President of the Liberal Party, very bluntly and crudely pointing out that if this intolerable behaviour of a Liberal Party representative-namely, Senator Puplick-was perpetuated there would not be any funds raised for the Liberal Party around Australia. But there is not a word of apology for that sort of action which I outlined in my speech of that night. It is dismissed in this misleading way in the paragraph on page 5 of the report.

Mr Harris is concerned that I commented on the fact that he enjoys certain positions which coincide with the tenure of Mr Hawke as Prime Minister. All I did was pass an observation on that. I did not comment on the correctness or incorrectness of it. Quite clearly, it is a matter of obvious distress to Mr Harris.

Mr Harris's letter to the Privileges Committee, I believe, has been a waste of time because none of his points stand up under analysis. Briefly, Mr Harris's history is that he has attacked Senator Puplick for exercising the proper duties of a senator in this Parliament, he has attacked me, and I am aware that he has issued a writ against another member of this Parliament because he dared to say that he was a friend of Mr Hawke. Hours and hours of the Senate's time have been taken up today by Senator Crichton-Browne talking about Mr Harris's stewardship as Chairman of the Australian Sports Commission. Quite clearly, Senator Crichton-Browne was telling the Senate that Mr Harris treated this Parliament with utter contempt.

When the drugs in sport committee sought answers to questions about how members of the Commission conducted themselves with respect to the provision of drugs and other matters, Mr Harris did not give them the courtesy of a measured response. Obviously, he took the view that Senator Black, as Chairman, Senator Crichton-Browne as Deputy Chairman, and other members of the Committee were ants to be crushed under his feet. The important thing was that he knew Mr Hawke and he was not going to answer to the Parliament for anything.

I do not have the slightest interest in how Mr Harris behaves and how he conducts his personal life, his social life, or his business life. My only concern is when it intrudes upon my own affairs and particularly in the discharge of my public duties. I will not be stood over, I will not be intimidated and I will not be bullied by any thugs in this country in the discharge of my public duties.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Tate) proposed:
That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I apologise for keeping the Senate, and I will be as brief as I can. Under the guise of questioning the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) about procedures for cleansing the electoral rolls in the remote areas of Western Australia, Senator Crichton-Browne patronised and denigrated his constituents and mine, implying that ballots had not been correctly conducted, specifically during mobile polling in the Kimberley.

SPEECH.PARA: He professed to be amazed at the high vote for the Australian Labor Party (ALP) and the low percentage of informal votes, making insulting assumptions about the political knowledge and perspicacity of the Aboriginal voters of the region who, incidentally, get their exposure to election propaganda in exactly the same way as most Australians do-via television. Those Aboriginal voters would have seen, as did many other Australians, the then Leader of the Opposition, Mr Peacock, committing himself to cutting funding for Aboriginal affairs.

Senator Crichton-Browne studiously ignored other obvious reasons for the high ALP vote and the low rate of informal voting. The electors in the Kimberley have every reason to take an intelligent interest in politics. They have a conscientious member in Graeme Campbell who has their interests at heart and who works tirelessly for his constituency. The same applies to the State Labor members, Ernie Bridge, Tom Stephens and Tom Helm.

Secondly, under Labor, both State and Federal, the Aborigines in this area, as in the rest of Australia, have seen dramatic changes in their standard of living over the last few years, encouragement of the out-station movement, greatly improved housing, health and education and, more than anything else, respect for their cultures and traditions.

Thirdly, the people in this area particularly recall clearly the Court of Disputed Returns in 1977 and the disgraceful incidents which led to that inquiry, including intimidation of voters and at least one attempt to intoxicate voters. The result of that Court of Disputed Returns was a damning indictment of the Western Australian Branch of the Liberal Party of Australia, at which time Senator Crichton-Browne was a very influential officer. The saga of Noonkanbah, that black blot on Western Australian Liberal history, occurred only 10 years ago-the blink of an eye compared with the centuries of Aboriginal history and tradition. Why would any Kimberley Aboriginal vote Liberal? This is tacitly acknowledged, I might say, by the fact that the Western Australian Liberal hierarchy apparently thought it pointless to send scrutineers to many of the Kimberley booths. I know of at least nine where there was no Liberal presence at all.

My observations of the 1990 election led me to believe that voter education had been thorough and effective, and I congratulate the Australian Electoral Commission and the Department of Aboriginal Affairs officers who were responsible for this. Those who were unable to vote because of infirmity or illiteracy knew very well that they were entitled to seek assistance, and that assistance was given by a range of people-not only scrutineers-and more often was given by officers of the Electoral Commission, community managers or leaders or other members of the communities, as is absolutely legitimate.

Aborigines demonstrated their capacity to actually conduct the ballot, under supervision of course, on this occasion. My experience once again led me to admire the way in which they were able to deal very effectively with the mechanics of conducting polling procedures. Despite what has been alleged, multiple voting would be most unlikely in areas of this sort because of the close knowledge of the officers of the Electoral Commission of the people who were assisting them, and the great affinity between particular groups in the area. It just would be known if one individual was appearing several times on the rolls, as has been alleged by Senator Crichton-Browne.

In Western Australia for decades there were attempts to stop people voting, to stop them getting onto the electoral rolls. This has completely changed. We are doing everything we can now to make certain that everybody has the opportunity to vote as, in fact, people are required to do by laws.

In completing my contribution this afternoon, I would like to recount what happened in Wiluna and Meekatharra in 1983. I witnessed pastoralists standing at the door of the Wiluna polling booth threatening Aboriginals that if they voted they would never again be employed in the area. At the Meekatharra polling booth, I heard the Liberal scrutineer say very loudly, `These people should not be allowed to vote. They don't even speak Australian'.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport and Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) One Ministerial Council exists.
(2) Its name is the Australian Transport Advisory Council (ATAC) and its objectives are:
(i) To review and co-ordinate various aspects of transport policy development and administration.
(ii) to initiate consultation and report to respective governments on any matter raised by the Council, or any State/Territory or the Commonwealth government, and to exercise advisory functions;

(iii) to report as necessary to respective governments on any matter which will tend to promote better co-ordination of transport development while at the same time encouraging the utmost modernisation and innovation possible to meet changing needs;
(iv) to provide a framework for development of codes of practice pertinent to transport and deemed necessary by the Council; and
(v) to assist in maintaining continuous and comprehensive research in relation to transport development in Australia and abroad.
(3) The Council determined in July 1988 to meet on an annual basis with additional meetings convened as required. Prior to that Council met twice yearly.
